name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-18
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
# 2.3.1. Topography
The 3D surface texture evolution was studied by means of a 3D Taylor Hobson Form Talysurf 120 surface profilometer. The dimension of the measured area is $3 \mathrm { x } 3 \ \mathrm { m m } ^ { 2 }$ . An assessment of height parameters (Sa, Sp, $\mathit { s v }$ , and $\$ 7$ ) characterizing the 3D surface topography was conducted according to ISO 25178 standard.

# 2.3.2. Residual porosity
The specimens were mechanically cut into vertical (section perpendicular to the deposited layers) and horizontal (section parallel to the deposited layers) cross-sections, ground and polished for examinations of superficial and volume defects according to a standard metallographic procedure. Then, the specimens were electrolytically etched at $1 . . . 2 \mathrm { ~ V ~ }$ dc by a Lucas' reagent consisting of the lactic acid $( 5 0 ~ \mathrm { m l } )$ , hydrochloric acid $\mathrm { 1 5 0 ~ m l ) }$ and oxalic acid (3 g) for 5 s to identify the places of formation of the aspherical pores. The residual porosity was observed by a Leica MEF4A optical microscope equipped with a digital camera, a TESCAN Mira 3 LMU scanning electron microscope (SEM), and the EDS measurements. Residual porosity was statistically analyzed using the Image-Pro Plus software. The area fractions and size distributions of pores in the build cross-sections of the SLM-built and post-processed specimens were estimated.
summary: 2.3. Specimen surface characterization, 2.3.3. Microhardness and residual macrostress measurements - Part 1/2

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-19
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
# 2.3.3. Microhardness and residual macrostress measurements
The microhardness depth profiles in the specimen cross-sections were measured along three parallel paths starting from the surface towards the core material using a tester Leica VMHT with a Vickers indenter loaded by 0.025 kgf $\mathrm { ( H V _ { 0 . 0 2 5 } ) }$ and the dwell time of ${ } ^ { 1 5 \ s . }$ . The standard deviation for the microhardness measurements was $\pm \nobreakspace 1 \nobreakspace$ HV. The surface microhardness in the near-surface layer was estimated at a depth of $1 5 . . . 2 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ from the top surface. In all cases, a total of five measurements were carried out at different treated zones and the averaged magnitudes were reported. Scatter of the experimental data did not exceed by $2 { - } 5 \%$ .

The X-ray diffraction (XRD) $\sin ^ { 2 } \psi$ based method was used to estimate the residual stress of the SLM-built and post-processed specimens using a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer in a $\mathrm { { C u K } _ { \alpha } }$ -radiation with a graphite monochromator at $3 0 ~ \mathrm { k V }$ and $3 0 ~ \mathrm { { m A } }$ , a 2θ $( 2 0 ^ { \circ } . . . 1 2 0 ^ { \circ } )$ scanning speed of $2 ~ \mathrm { ^ { o } / m i n }$ . The depth distributions of residual stress were performed by a stepwise electrolytic polishing [38,51]. The grain/ crystallite analysis in the subsurface layer of about $1 0 . . . 2 0 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ was carried out by the XRD method as well.

# 3. Results
summary: 2.3. Specimen surface characterization, 2.3.3. Microhardness and residual macrostress measurements - Part 2/2

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-20
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
The surface topography of the SLM-built and post-processed IN 718 specimens are compared in Figs. 3 and 4. The 3D assessment of surface texture parameters was estimated by the arithmetic mean height $( S a )$ the maximum peak height $( S p )$ , the maximum valley height $( S \nu )$ and the maximum height $( S z )$ of the surface irregularities (Fig. 5).

As usual, the morphology of the side surfaces of SLM-built specimen contains a large number of manufacturing defects, such as ellipsoidal/ spherical balls or shrinkage cavities, partially melted powder particles or spattering powder particles, open pores, and signs of the laser tracks (Figs. 3a,b, and 4a–d) [57]. In addition to that, the surface is rough (Sz parameter is ${ \sim } 6 0 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ having the irregularities of relatively high height (Figs. 3, 5). It is seen that the partially melted metal powder or spatters (indicated by arrows in Fig. 4b) are adhered to the surface specimen because of their existence inside the heat-affected zone [40]. Fig. 4c shows a general view of balling that formed alongside the surface via a segmentation effect of the elongated melt pool [52]. The balling phenomenon is usually formed during the SLM process when the molten pool becomes discontinuous and breaks into separated islands via a shrinking tendency to decrease the surface energy under the action of surface tension. Additionally, the unmolten powder particles were found in the near-surface layer (indicated by arrows in Fig. 4d). As a result, above-mentioned defects essentially deteriorate surface integrity. In order to reduce or eliminate surface defects, the surface mechanical methods are usually applied [45–48,50–53].

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-21
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content: The typical surface texture of the SLM-built specimens formed after various mechanical surface treatments is also shown in Figs. 3 and 4. In particular, the BF and USP processes do not result in a significant change in the surface texture in comparison with the SLM-built specimen. As compared to the Sa parameter characterizing the surface roughness of the SLM-built specimen, the $s a$ magnitudes evaluated after the BF and USP processes were respectively diminished just by $2 0 \%$ and $3 4 \%$ (Figs. 3, 5). Nevertheless, it should be noted that the ellipsoidal and spherical balls were successfully removed from these surfaces (Fig. 4f,j). In addition to that, the BF and USP processes provide a ${ \sim } 5 0 \%$ reduction in the total height parameter $( P t )$ of surface profile in comparison with the SLM-built state (Fig. 3).

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-22
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content: In contrast to the BF and USP processes, both SP and UIT led to the formation of new surface microreliefs on the post-processed SLM-built specimens (Figs. 3e,f,i, and $^ { 4 } \mathbf { g } , \mathbf { k } )$ , reducing adverse surface defects. As compared to the SP process $( S a = 6 . 6 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ , $S z = 5 6 . 7 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ , UIT forms regular microrelief with a smoother surface (the $\scriptstyle { S z }$ parameter is ${ \sim } 2 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ and lower surface waviness owing to the application of the multi-pin ultrasonic tool, which produces the sliding impacts of pins by the specimen surface due to forced rotation of the impact head [38] (Figs. 3 and 5). The registered UIT-caused $s a$ parameter becomes twice lower than that of the SLM-built specimen. It is also important to point out that the dimpled surface microreliefs formed by USP and SP are significantly different due to the fact that the balls driven by the directional compressed air flow in the case of the SP process hit nearly perpendicular to the treated surface, while in the case of the USP process the balls impacted the treated surface in random angles owing to their chaotic motion inside the USP-chamber. Therefore, in contrast to USP, the SP-induced surface relief is more significantly affected by the shot speed. Additionally, a larger diameter of the shot media and multidirectional character of impacts in the case of USP can be the reason of slightly decreased surface texture parameters as compared to that formed after SP (Fig. 5). This result also correlates well with the literature data [53]. The reduction in the surface texture parameters and the modification homogeneity induced by SP and USP could be increased when the higher-energy shots would be applied for a longer time [54].

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-23
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
In our experimental conditions, in comparison with the SLM-built state the surface roughness $( S a ~ = ~ 5 . 2 7 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ of the post-processed specimens were respectively decreased by $2 0 . 6 \%$ , $2 6 . 2 \%$ , and $5 7 . 4 \%$ after the BF, USP, and UIT processes except for the SP-treated ones (Fig. 5). It should be noted that the $\scriptstyle { S z }$ parameter was reduced in all treated SLM-built specimens except for the SP-treated ones.

![](images/3b2c991bd058bd42275a0da8bbc0cb10787e8f7009766729b98e41a08d4ed9c3.jpg)  
Fig. 3. The surface profile and 3D texture of the SLM-built (a) and BF (b), SP (c), USP (d), and UIT (e) processed IN 718 specimens.

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-24
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
Along with the surface microrelief parameters, the residual internal porosity in the near-surface layers is also of special importance for the wear/corrosion and fatigue resistance of a material. The residual porosity near the specimen surface was studied in the build (Z-axis) and scan (XY-axis) directions (Figs. 6–8).

![](images/76a850c667e5792629b02fdeea4549659feabc7eb92736c18f4c1849997fbf4e.jpg)  
Fig. 4. The surface morphology and images of the near-surface layer of the SLM-built (a–d) and BF (e,f), SP $^ { ( g , \mathrm { h } ) }$ , USP $( \mathrm { i } , \mathrm { j } )$ , and UIT $^ { ( \mathrm { k } , \mathrm { l } ) }$ processed IN 718 specimens.

![](images/0360e69233a940c17d2c7ae48e5f80cac11d202fb7be966c3b5cd4f57deea435.jpg)  
Fig. 5. Surface texture parameters of the SLM-built and BF, SP, USP, and UIT processed IN 718 specimens.

Considering the near-surface layers, the highest area fraction of the pores is naturally seen in the SLM-built specimen, which can be explained to the inclusion of gases in the deposited layers during the melting and solidification processes (Fig. 6a). It is known that the SLM process is able to produce nearly full dense $( 9 8 . . . 9 9 \% )$ parts with some residual porosity in a form of a keyhole, spherical or shrinkage pores [40].

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-25
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content: The subsurface porosity in the SLM-built specimen can be seen in Fig. 6a. At least two types of defects are visible here. In particular, the spherical pores (gas pores) caused by the incompleteness of the gas release from the melt during the SLM process (indicated by arrows in Figs. 7a, 8a). The gas bubbles of the spherical shape formed in a molten pool can further be ‘frozen’ in the solidified part as spherical pores. More rarely, the aspherical pores (also known as lack-of-fusion defects) might be formed between the previously deposited layers and scan tracks due to insufficient melting of the powder layer before the solidification stage [55]. The aspherical pores can be found to be oriented parallel, perpendicularly or at some angle with regard to the build direction (indicated by arrows in Fig. 7b). The defects in the SLM-built specimen varied in size from 1 to $5 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ .

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-26
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content: From the quality point of view of the SLM-printed metal parts of a high level of residual porosity require additional post-processing, for instance by the methods of severe plastic deformation, to eliminate or diminish the residual porosity at least in the near-surface layers. The results of a statistical analysis of the area fractions and size distributions of residual pores show that the surface porosity percentage is decreased irrespective of the treatment method used (Figs. 9). Pores of different size were observed in the specimens along the build direction. The smallest size of pores was registered after the USP and UIT processes due to effective pores closure induced by severe plastic deformation of high strain rate and high extent supplemented by ultrasonic action [56]. Based on the quantitative porosity analysis, the residual porosity values after USP and UIT processes were respectively decreased by 55 and $8 4 \%$ as compared to the SLM-built specimen (Fig. 9). Compared to the USP process, the UIT process significantly decreases and virtually removes the near-surface porosity, forming a deeper densified layer $( \sim 2 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ . It is seen that spherical ball or unmelted powder (Fig. 8a) is deformed by the multi-pin ultrasonic tool (Fig. 8f). As a result, the smallest number of pores was observed after the UIT process $( 0 . 1 1 8 \% )$ , which seems to be fully eliminated if the higher oscillation amplitude and/or treatment duration would be used (Figs. 6–8). It was also shown in our earlier studies that multi-pin UIT can result in effective pores closure in the treated surface layer of the powder metallurgy Ti6Al4V alloy [35]. Recently, Wang et al. [9] also shown that ultrasonic surface rolling of the SLM-built Ti6Al4V alloy was able to form the pore-free surface layer of ${ \sim } 2 0 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ thick.

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-27
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
Further thermal treatment can be expected to provide the healing of these closed pores and thus to enhance the overall material properties.

![](images/1a6cbfec8396e9a5de856f8d5501c1b8241d988bbadd7e96e460c1501b5d3363.jpg)  
Fig. 6. Residual porosity in the build direction of the SLM-built (a) and BF (b), SP (c), USP (d), and UIT (e) processed IN 718 specimens.

In contrast to the USP and UIT processes, the BF and SP led to a lesser reduction in subsurface porosity $( { \sim } 2 0 . . . 4 0 \% )$ )(Figs. 9). In addition to that, the large oval-shape pores (Fig. 6b, c) or aspherical shape pores (indicated by arrows in Figs. 7c, e, 8e) were detected in the nearsurface area. This result also correlates with the literature data, where the SP process using steel balls reduces the porosity in an aluminum alloy by $1 5 { - } 3 0 \%$ at the depth up to $5 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ [42].

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-28
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
# 3.3. Hardness
A typical near-surface microhardness depth profiles after application of different post-processing techniques are shown in Fig. 10. The surface microhardness of the SLM-built specimen $( \mathrm { H V } _ { 0 . 0 2 5 } \approx 3 9 0 )$ is increased after application of all post-processing techniques that is seemingly originated owing to the increasing dislocation density and some grain/crystallite refinement. The $\mathrm { H V } _ { 0 . 0 2 5 }$ magnitudes achieve ${ \sim } 4 5 0$ , ${ \sim } 4 8 0$ , ${ \sim } 5 9 0$ , and ${ \sim } 6 5 0$ after BF, USP, UIT, and SP, respectively. The microhardness of the surface layers of the BF and USP processed specimens are higher than that of the SLM-built specimen by $\sim 1 5 . . .$ $2 5 \%$ . At the same time, as compared to the SLM-built specimen $( 4 1 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ , the crystallite size in the near-surface layer was found slightly decreased after BF $( \sim 3 4 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ and USP $( \sim 2 3 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ , respectively, The UIT process led to a $5 0 \%$ increase in the near-surface hardness, forming the crystallite size of ${ \sim } 1 5 ~ { \mu } \mathrm { m }$ , as compared to the untreated SLM-built specimen, while the SP-induced surface microhardness is approximately $1 0 \%$ higher than that of the UIT-processed specimen. Additionally, the crystallite size magnitude is the smallest after the SP process $( \sim 1 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ .

Analyzing the HV depth profiles one can conclude that the hardening depth is the lowest $( \sim 8 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ after the BF process. The thicker hardened layer $( \sim 1 4 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ were produced by the USP process, while the deepest hardened layers $( \sim 1 8 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ was respectively formed after the UIT and SP processes. These observations correlate well with the impact energy accumulated in the surface layers treated by different post-processing techniques (Table 3).

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-29
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
# 3.4. Residual stress
From point of view of desirable prolonged operation life of the SLMbuilt parts, the sign and magnitude of residual stresses are additional critical characteristics. In this study, they were assessed using the X-ray stress analysis. Considering the residual stress magnitudes formed in the subsurface layers of the studied specimens, the tensile residual stresses formed in the SLM-built specimen $\mathrm { ( + 1 2 0 ~ M P a ) }$ ) because of the large thermal gradients occurred near the laser spot during rapid heating and cooling of the molten pool (Fig. 11) [21] were successfully eliminated by post-processing techniques. Moreover, the residual stresses formed by post-processing techniques are of the compressive character.

![](images/7cea315956fd17160edfd01721ea1561db2da8b41d138de3e638e9f43bdbf632.jpg)  
Fig. 7. SEM micrographs of residual porosity in the build direction of the SLM-built (a,b) and BF (c), USP (d), SP (e), and UIT (f) processed IN 718 specimens.

The estimated magnitude of the BF-induced stresses $( - 2 0 1 . 4 \ \mathrm { M P a } )$ is the lowest in comparison with those registered after the USP $( - 3 1 3 . 8 \ \mathrm { M P a } )$ , multi-pin UIT $\mathrm { ( - 4 2 8 . 7 ~ M P a ) }$ , and SP $\left( - 5 1 0 . 7 \ \mathrm { M P a } \right)$ processes. It is also important that the SP, USP and UIT processes generate compressive residual stresses in rather deep subsurface layers $( \sim 1 4 0 { - } 1 8 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ . It is, therefore, could be expected that these compressive stresses would be beneficial in the improvement of any surfacerelated operational properties of SLM-fabricated specimens/parts (fatigue life, wear, and corrosion resistance).

![](images/47dff9bc81cd170e0d704be843fa3543c787307db3faa7b1ff6b427bb6b17d50.jpg)  
Fig. 8. SEM micrographs of residual porosity in the scan direction of the SLM-built (a,b) and BF (c), USP (d), SP (e), and UIT (f) processed IN 718 specimens.

# 4. Discussion

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-30
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
The experimental results presented above (Figs. 3, 4) have indicated that the surface of SLM-fabricated parts contains a large number of manufacturing defects (surface balls, partially melted or sputtered powder particles, shrinkage cavities and/or open pores), which are usual for the SLM manufactured parts [25,40]. Various SLM parameters (laser energy density, hatch spacing, scanning speed) were shown to affect the surface topography of the IN 718 parts [25]. For instance, the balling effect (needle-like tips and deep pits) was decreased at a higher energy density. It was concluded that lower hatch spacing allowed producing the parts with smoother surfaces [57]. The results of this study, as well as some literature data [8,9,13,14] show that mechanical post-processing of the SLM-built parts can be another effective technological solution. Severe plastic deformation (SPD) of the treated surfaces can be able to reduce the manufacturing defects, although mainly in the near-surface layers. Often, it is enough to improve the surface characteristics of the SLM-built parts to meet the stringent requirements in various engineering applications.

![](images/c034da2f6a9e53ab812ae8ed0bd708282345d88871bceaead14c673d869735db.jpg)  
Fig. 9. Relative porosity in the build direction of the SLM-built and BF, SP, USP, and UIT processed IN 718 specimens.

![](images/aefbf0aab0930ad18117928d09b0ec2d8a5cf07e75230e76eb52127577a4adb2.jpg)  
Fig. 10. Microhardness distribution in the build direction of the SLM-built and BF, SP, USP, and UIT processed IN 718 specimens.

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-31
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
Changes in the surface roughness parameters (Fig. 5) observed in this study well correlate to the appropriate literature data [13,37,40–42]. In particular, the SP process caused the almost $5 0 \%$ reduction in the surface roughness of SLM-built AlSi10Mg specimen $( R a \ = \ 1 1 . 9 6 \ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ [40]. However, as compared to the machined or machined-and-polished surfaces, the SP processed surface acquired the increased roughness magnitudes [41]. On the other hand, such postprocessing techniques as a media blasting, tumbling, LSP, and UNSM were shown to improve the surface texture of the SLM-fabricated metal components. It is also important that the multi-pin UIT process can results in a regular surface microrelief with lower surface waviness and roughness as compared to those formed after SP, and USP, which produce random impacts of high-energy balls by the components surface [38,39,47].

The extent of the roughness changes induced by different postprocessing mechanical techniques can be illustrated with respect to the accumulated impact energy $E$ (Table 3) using Fig. 12. Generally, it can be concluded that all mechanical surface treatments applied in this study are very effective for improving the surface microrelief parameters of the SLM-built parts – the surface roughness linearly decreases with accumulating energy, which correlates to the surface deformation extent (Table 3). Only data related to the SP-processed specimen $( E \approx 3 . 1 5 ~ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 2 } } )$ ) stand out of the linear dependence that can be explained by the impacting features – the SP-induced impacts are directed perpendicularly to the treated surface, and thus they induce higher acquired roughness. The presented data can be easily used to choose optimal regimes of other mechanical surface treatments provided the $E$ would be known.

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-32
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
Fig. 13 shows SEM images of the surface topographies of the SLMbuilt and post-processed specimens. It is seen that the SLM-built surface is relatively smooth without a lot of intrusions and extrusions (Fig. 13, a1), which correlates well to the surface topography shown in Fig. 3, a. However, it contains numerous partially melted powder particles attached to the surface (Fig. 13, a1–a3) and some portion of the shrinkage cavities (Fig. 13, a1, a2). The surface topographies after mechanical post-processing (Fig. 13, b1–d1) become smoother with the increased accumulated energy applied. Still, some deformed particles are seen in the BF-processed (Fig. 13, b1) and USP processed (Fig. 13, c1) surfaces. Conversely, the SP (Fig. 13, d1) and UIT (Fig. 13, e1) modified surfaces are almost completely free from such manufacturing defects. Only some residuals of surface filaments can be seen (Fig. 13, d2, e2).

Finally, when the complex-shape or small-sized products need to be treated one should account for more convenience and higher productivity of the BF, USP, LSP, SP, media blasting and tumbling processes with regard to the multi-pin UIT process. In particular, SP, USP, and LSP are usually used to treat the turbine blades, aircraft wings, and other curved surfaces to reduce aerodynamic drag as the dimpled surfaces are known to have a lesser aerodynamic drag than that of extremely smooth surfaces.

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-33
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
Porosity is another feature determining the quality and operation life of the AM products. Formation of the defects in the SLM large-scale components was shown to be unavoidable [58]. According to the literature data, the manufacturing defects may play the role of stress risers, and they thus may reduce the fatigue life and wear resistance of the fabricated metal components [27,41]. For instance, the SLM-built AlSi7Mg specimen having $1 \%$ of porosity demonstrated the fatigue life decreased by $5 0 \%$ in comparison with that of the dense alloy [42]. The most frequent sites for fatigue cracks' initiations are pores (Fig. 14) or unmelted particles in the near-surface area irrespective of the load conditions or stress state [28]. It should be noted that as compared to the gas (spherical) pores, the aspherical pores cause a significant deterioration of mechanical properties of the material due to their larger size [14,25,26,42].

To minimize the porosity optimum regimens for SLM process can be found and used. It was revealed that the densest IN 718 alloy specimens with a relative density of $9 9 . 7 3 \%$ can be fabricated with the laser power of 245 W, scanning speed of $7 5 5 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ and hatch spacing of $9 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ [55]. Work by Mancisidor et al. [24] showed that a combination of optimum scanning speed $\left( 6 0 0 . . . 8 0 0 \ \mathrm { \ m m } / { s } \right)$ and focus offset (8… $1 0 \ \mathrm { m m }$ ) can significantly reduce the porosity both in the hatch and borders irrespective of the scanning strategies used.

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-34
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
Use of post-processing treatments is another way to improve the properties of the SLM-built parts. On the one hand, a hot isostatic pressing (HIP) treatment is able to eliminate/minimize porosity in the material volume, and thus it is one of the most effective approaches. Compared to the initial value of porosity $( \sim 0 . 6 \% )$ of the vacuum induction melted IN 718 superalloy, the porosity was reduced using HIP treatment, and the extent of this reduction was proportional to the soaking time decreasing to $0 . 1 3 6 \%$ (by $\sim 7 8 \% )$ and $0 . 0 8 2 \%$ (by $8 6 \%$ ) after HIP treatment for 2 and $^ { 4 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ , respectively [59].

![](images/e99d710703ee847cfeea4805e9b57fbdb3100eea36f0e2835b530b7bd5221d39.jpg)  
Fig. 11. Residual stress depth profiles formed in the build direction of the SLMbuilt and BF, SP, USP, and UIT processed IN 718 specimens.

![](images/f426b9eeaf46a8853c78401b5bb96e9106e709de504b8c8bacaa0664fae8aeee.jpg)  
Fig. 12. Dependencies of roughness $s a$ (1) and porosity $P \%$ (2) on the accumulated impact energy $E$ . Dashed lines indicate the apparent trends.

On the other hand, the SPD methods can also be used for the improvement purposes tough they are able to diminish porosity mainly in the near-surface layers. In our case, the USP and UIT processes led to the porosity decrease (by 55 and $8 4 \%$ ) in the top layers of the specimens $( 0 . 3 1 7 \%$ and $0 . 1 1 8 \%$ , respectively) seemingly because of the specific deformation conditions operated at these processes (multidirectional sliding impacts inducing simultaneous action of both normal and lateral components of the load) [35]. Indeed, such conditions were concluded to be more effective for the micro-pore closure than only hydrostatic compressive stress [35,60].

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-35
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
Curve 2 in Fig. 12 shows that the higher the accumulated impact energy of the mechanical post-processing treatment applied the lower the residual porosity becomes. A linear trend indicated by the dashed line is apparent. Less extent of the porosity decrease observed in the case of SP $( 1 . 2 6 { \mathrm { ~ k J } } )$ than expected following the shown linear trend seems to be caused by a lesser lateral component of the SP-induced impacts. According to the data obtained in this study, the UIT is the most effective in the pores closure. However, it is hard to use it for porosity management in the complex-shape parts, which can be more easily treated by any of the techniques operated with spherical impacting media (BF, USP, and SP).

Mechanical post-processing of the SLM-built specimens can be used either as finishing treatment or as an intermediate process between the SLM steps (applied every several molten/solidified layers). Recently, it was shown that the ultrasonic peening applied after deposition of every two SLM layers facilitated the production of full density parts [9]. It might partially substitute such expensive method as HIP.

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-36
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
Hardness and stress state of any material (especially, in the nearsurface layers) are also crucial characteristics with respect to their operational life and durability. These parameters are naturally very important in consideration of the SLM-built parts and they were analyzed in the literature.

It is known that one of the possible ways to minimize residual stress at the SLM process is a variation of the scanning strategy [17,24,27]. A scanning strategy is chosen depends on the part geometry. The stripe or chessboard scanning strategies are suitable for parts with thicker sections. Above-mentioned scanning strategies can generate a homogeneous distribution of residual stresses via shorter scan vectors. The heating of the build plate during the AM process is another technique, which is able to reduce residual stress. While the post-process heat or mechanical surface treatments can also relieve the harmful stresses in already built-up AM parts.

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-37
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
Recently, Wang et al. reported that ultrasonic surface rolling resulted in the hardening of the surface layer of the SLM-built Ti-6Al-4 V alloy of $1 0 0 . . . 2 0 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ thick, and a maximum surface hardness was registered to be of $4 1 0 . . . 4 3 0 \ \mathrm { H V } _ { 0 . 1 }$ [9]. Increase in the hardness, shear resistance, and inhibition of the delamination initiation was concluded to be the reasons for the improvement of the AM parts by ultrasonic surface rolling [9]. Work by Zhang et al. [8] showed that the residual stress can be largely reduced by the UIT during the SLM process. In addition to that, it was revealed that the tensile residual stresses in the SLM-built specimen $( 1 7 6 . 3 \mathrm { M P a } )$ ) can be reduced after UIT (49.9 MPa). Recently, the LSP process combined with the SLM process was implemented to decrease/eliminate the thermal residual stresses during the SLM process [10]. Moreover, work by Damon et al. [42] showed that the SP process shifted the maximum of the compressive residual stress profile towards the deeper layers.

As shown in this study, all used surface mechanical treatments resulted in the surface hardening (Figs. 10, 15) and in the formation of compressed layers (Figs. 11, 15). Naturally, both microhardness and compressive stresses increase with the accumulated energy since it correlates to the extent of the surface deformation (Table 3). However, some decrease in the HV and $\sigma _ { \mathrm { R } }$ magnitudes after UIT with regard to those observed after SP seems to be related to the sliding character of UIT produced impact, which is in contrast to the normal impacts mainly occurred at the SP process.

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-38
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
Since various post-processing mechanical treatments formed the hardened and compressed layers of different thickness it would be more reasonable to analyze them accounting these thicknesses, for instance, using the hardness intensity gradient $I _ { \mathrm { h a r d } }$ . This parameter can be calculated with regard to several layer thicknesses (say, 25, 50, and $1 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } )$ using the following expression [51]:

$$
I _ { \mathrm { h a r d } } = \mathrm { ( H V _ { h a r d } - H V _ { a s - b u i l t } ) } / h _ { \mathrm { h a r d } } ,
$$

where $\mathrm { H V } _ { \mathrm { a s - b u i l t } }$ and $\mathrm { H V _ { h a r d } }$ are the microhardness magnitudes of the SLM-built and hardened specimens (MPa), respectively, $h _ { \mathrm { h a r d } }$ is the thickness of the considered layer possessing enhanced hardness $\left( \mu \mathrm { m } \right)$ .

The dependences of the hardness intensity gradient $I _ { \mathrm { h a r d } }$ on the accumulated impact energy $\hat { E }$ are presented in Fig. 16 (curves 2–4). They can characterize the effectiveness of the used mechanical surface treatment in a view of the hardening-to-depth ratio. It is seen that the

![](images/d49be22562af46c441ad839c7524d594b91f4b61a4d845491d6db63a67d3c2f2.jpg)

Fig. 13. SEM images of the surface topographies of the SLM-built (a1–a3) specimen and specimens post-processed by BF (b1–b3), USP (c1–c3), SP (d1–d3), and UIT (e1–e3) treatments.

![](images/09daeaa83f26d128878c0159b69a5d0c79f41ccb691c5d263da85cda21672cf2.jpg)  
Fig. 14. SEM image of the spherical pore in the scan direction of the SLM-built IN 718 specimen.

![](images/89a2ed9b4ffe49e16a7e9a883ee028b618978b2e12d4d34dc575203559c719e7.jpg)  
Fig. 15. Dependencies of microhardness $\mathrm { H V } _ { 0 . 0 2 5 }$ (1) and residual stress (2) on the accumulated impact energy $E$ . Dashed lines indicate the apparent trends.

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-39
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
hardness intensity after the SP $( E = 1 . 2 6 ~ \mathrm { k J } )$ ) and UIT $( E = 1 . 6 8 \ \mathrm { k J } )$ processes remain high enough in the surface layers of various thicknesses up to $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ (Fig. 16, curves 2–4). Thus, in view of the hardness intensity gradient, the UIT and SP processes would obviously result in a longer operating life of the processed SLM-parts as compared to those undergoing BF or USP.

Another important parameter, which can be used to assess the possibility of further improvement of the SLM-built part, is the local plasticity characteristics $\delta _ { \mathrm { H } }$ presenting a fraction of the plastic strain in the total elastoplastic strain (the ability of the material to plastic deformation). It can be determined by the indentation method using a Vickers pyramidal indenter according to the formula [51]:

$$
\delta _ { \mathrm H } = 1 - 1 4 . 3 ( 1 - \mu - 2 \mu ^ { 2 } ) \frac { \mathrm { H V } } { E } ,
$$

where HV is the microhardness of the surface layer (GPa); $\mu$ is the Poisson's coefficient $( \mu = 0 . 2 7 8 )$ ), $E$ is Young's modulus $( E = 2 0 0 \mathrm { G P a } )$ . Possible variation of $E$ due to changing porosity was assumed negligible. The dependence of the local plasticity characteristic $\delta _ { \mathrm { H } }$ on the accumulated impact energy $E$ is shown in Fig. 16 (curve 5). Actually, all mechanical surface treatments insignificantly decrease the material plasticity, and thus they can be further applied for a longer time without danger of premature brittle destruction of the SLM-built part.

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-40
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
![](images/f1cb5ad24ed394cf4c66a88db4c46b9bf66477d4bc57ece036962c4be5357a54.jpg)  
Fig. 16. Dependencies of microhardness $\mathrm { H V } _ { 0 . 0 2 5 }$ of the near-surface layer (1), hardness intensity gradient $I _ { \mathrm { h a r d } }$ (2–4) for the layer thicknesses of $2 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ (2), $5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ (3) and $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ (4), and local plasticity characteristics $\delta _ { \mathrm { H } }$ (5) in the build direction of the SLM-built IN 718 specimens on the accumulated impact energy E.

This information could be useful when the sequence of the procedures applied during the combined AM process (for instance, consisting of SLM and intermediate mechanical surface treatments) would be chosen [7–10]. Since the application of mechanical treatments every SLM-built layer would cause more time consuming it would be better to apply them every several SLM-formed layers, and both the material quality improvement and SLM process efficiency requirements would be satisfied. Analyzing the $\delta _ { \mathrm { H } }$ parameter allows preventing undesirable overstraining at the intermediate application of mechanical surface treatments during the SLM manufacturing. Work by Zhang [8] confirmed that the UIT process applied after the deposition of 2–3 layers reduced both the long columnar grains and structural defects, and it formed compressive residual macrostress in the SLM-built parts. The ultrasonic peening applied after deposition of every two SLM layers was also shown to facilitate the densification of the SLM-built part up to ‘full’ dense of conventionally cast material [9].

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-41
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
Type of appropriate post-processing technique can be chosen based on the analysis of the shape and dimensions of the part to be treated. While the regimes of the chosen post-processing treatments can be determined, accounting for the extents of the surface roughness reduction, manufacturing defects and porosity eliminations, hardening/ compressing, and the thickness of modified layers. Fig. 16 compares the relative efficiency of the used mechanical surface treatments with regard their ability to change several studied characteristics. Some of these characteristics (roughness, porosity) were decreased after application of the post-processing techniques, but the others (HV, residual stresses, and penetration depth) were increased/enhanced. An appropriate mechanical method can be chosen accounting for this data and considering the applicability of various techniques for post-processing of the small-sized, large-scale, and complex-shape parts (see the ‘versatility’ parameter in Fig. 17).

It is also important to take a controllability/convenience and cost/ time consuming of intermediate mechanical surface treatments into account. The BF (or media blasting and tumbling) and SP (or cavitation peening, USP, LSP) processes are rather controllable/flexible, but they can be used predominantly for surface finishing of the SLM-built products. Conversely, the UIT, UNSM or LSP processes can provide local treatment both at the intermediate stages (every several SLM-built layers) and after the end of the SLM-process. However, they need more effort to meet the precision requirements before including them to the SLM-manufacturing routes used for complex-shape components [10]. Additionally, as compared to the SP and cavitation peening, the LSP process is known to be more expensive. Nevertheless, the LSP process can provide individually controlled shots and the deeper layers compressed by residual stress [9].

Fig. 17. Summarized results of surface roughness, porosity, hardness, residual stress, penetration and 3D process versatility. Marker $\scriptstyle \mathbf { \bar { 0 } } ^ { \prime }$ indicates the SLM-built condition, and markers ${ \bf \Delta } ^ { \circ } { \bf 1 } ^ { \prime } - { \bf \Delta } ^ { \circ } { \bf 4 } ^ { \prime }$ mean the gradation of relative efficiency of the used mechanical post-processing techniques in changing various characteristics.

name: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel-part-43
fileName: 2020 - Surface and Coatings Technology - Lesyk et al. - Post-processing of the Inconel 718 alloy parts fabricated by selective laser mel.md
content:
Application of the mechanical post-processing techniques, such as SP [12,43], LSP [10], mono-pin UIT [8,61], multi-pin UIT [11,38,39], UNSM [19,37], to the SLM-built parts allow reducing both superficial and structural defects, ensuring the surface hardening and compressing of the surface layers of the parts. Therefore, such a technological solution allows manufacturing the complex products for the aerospace industry without changing their design or material, but only by applying additional mechanical post-processing to improve their operational properties.

Type of appropriate post-processing technique can be chosen based on the analysis of the shape and dimensions of the part to be treated. While the regimes of the chosen post-processing treatments can be determined, accounting for the extents of the surface roughness reduction, manufacturing defects and porosity eliminations, hardening/ compressing, and the thickness of modified layers (see Fig. 17).

The BF, SP, USP, and UIT processes applied in this study to improve the IN 718 alloy specimens manufactured by the SLM process demonstrated a good efficiency for modification of the surface topography, porosity, hardness and residual stress. The obtained results allow drawing the following conclusions:

• In comparison with the SLM-built state the surface roughness $( S a = 5 . 2 7 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ of the post-processed specimens were respectively decreased by $2 0 . 6 \%$ , $2 6 . 2 \%$ , and $5 7 . 4 \%$ after the BF, USP, and UIT processes except for the SP-treated ones. The $\scriptstyle { S z }$ parameter was reduced in all treated SLM-built specimens except for the SP-treated ones; • Compared to the residual porosity of the SLM-built specimen

content:
Subin Shrestha1 & Kevin Chou1

Received: 13 April 2021 /Accepted: 15 April 2021 / Published online: 23 April 2021

summary: An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of Inconel 625 powder: single track geometry and porosity

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In-part-2
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In.md
content: The laser process parameters used in selective laser melting (SLM) affect the mode of melting and the process characteristics such as the porosity. Some parameters may have a higher effect on the single-track characteristics than the others. This study aims at determining both the individual and combined effects of laser parameters on the single-track geometry and porosity for Inconel 625 alloy powder. The single tracks with linear energy densities (LED) ranging from 0.16 to $0 . 9 8 \mathrm { J / m m }$ are fabricated to explore the effect of LED on melting modes and the keyhole porosity. A micro-CT scanner is used to measure the pores formed inside the tracks, and the results showed that the porosity increased with an increase in LED in the keyhole mode. Besides, metallography is performed to reveal the transverse melt pool boundary and to differentiate the melting modes. The transverse melt pool boundary shows that the depth of the melt pool increases significantly compared to the width with an increase in LED, which signifies the change in the melting from the conduction to keyhole mode. Further, another set of experiments is performed by using different combinations of laser power and scan speed from the same LEDs of $0 . 4 8 ~ \mathrm { J / m m }$ and $0 . 7 5 ~ \mathrm { J / m m }$ . The melt pool boundary shows that within the same LED, the depth of the melt pool increases significantly with an increase in the laser power. However, for the same LED, the single-track porosity increased up to a certain level; then, the porosity decreased with the further increase in the power and speed. The physics behind such phenomenon is explained by the particle-level SLM process simulations developed using FLOW-3D. The simulation results show that the change in the melting mode from the conduction to keyhole for the same LED is due to the increased vaporization with an increase in the laser power, which enhanced the vapor pressure.

fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In.md

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In-part-4
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In.md
content:
Additive manufacturing (AM) is a layer-wise fabrication process which enables the production of complex geometries. Selective laser melting (SLM) is a powder bed AM process that uses metal powder as the feedstock material. During the SLM process, the metal powder is spread over the build platform layer by layer, and the laser is used to melt the powder particles selectively to form a designed part. SLM process has been used to produce parts from different materials. Gu et al. [1] investigated the densification behavior and microstructure evolution of pure titanium, while Leuders et al. [2] studied the fatigue resistance and crack growth performance of TI6Al4V manufactured by SLM process. Moreover, Li et al. [3] studied the balling behavior of stainless steel and nickel powder during the SLM process.

Although the SLM process has shown its freeform capability, the variability induced by the process itself impedes the establishment of a process standard as described by Monzón et al. [4]. The process variables include laser power, scan speed, hatch spacing, powder size distribution, layer thickness, ambient pressure, inert atmosphere, etc. Lee et al. [5] have used a data analytics approach to find the correlation between different parameters with the melt pool properties such as track width, depth, etc. The results showed that the depth and width of melt pool are physically relevant with the laser penetration, and fluid convection, respectively.

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In-part-5
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In.md
content: The single-track studies are mostly used to observe the track morphology and the melt pool boundary. Yadroitsev et al. [6] analyzed the SLM single tracks formed with metal powders and showed that there exist stability and instability zones. Dilip et al. [7] discussed the effect of laser parameters on the melt pool shape and size and used a transverse melt pool boundary to distinguish the modes of melting. The shape of the melt pool boundary formed in the conduction mode is usually semi-circular, and the depth is close to the half-width of the track. However, the depth is higher than the half-width of the track in the keyhole mode melting, as explained by King et al. [8]. Cunningham et al. [9] used ultrahigh-speed synchrotron x-ray imaging to observe the melt pool formation during the SLM process. Such experiments enable the realtime observation of the development of vapor depression. The authors concluded based on the power density that there is a well-defined threshold from conduction mode to keyhole. Similarly, Martin et al. [10] studied the dynamics of the pore formation during the SLM process. In situ X-ray imaging was utilized to understand the formation of vapor depression, and the effect of laser power on the depression depth was assessed. The results indicated that under steady-state scan conditions, the vapor depression increases linearly with the laser power, and the pores are formed due to the collapse of the keyhole wall. Besides, Shrestha and Chou [11] showed that the numerical simulations could be used to understand the characteristics of the conduction mode melting and keyhole mode melting.

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In-part-6
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In.md
content: Pang et al. [12] demonstrated that the instability in the keyhole walls might lead to the formation of the keyhole pores. Micro-computed tomography (micro-CT)-based studies help to detect and characterize internal pores formed during the SLM process. Shrestha et al. [13] and Thanki et al. [14] performed the single-track experiments and utilized the microCT to characterize the keyhole pores formed inside the tracks. The size of the keyhole pores depends on the process parameter used, and the keyhole porosity increase with the increase in the linear energy density (LED). Most of the studies used the energy density, a thermodynamic quantity, to characterize the single tracks and part quality. However, Bertoli et al. [15] explained that the melt pool characteristics in the laser material processing depend on the process parameters such as laser power, scan speed, and beam diameter and material properties such as surface absorption, thermal conductivity, and thermal diffusivity. Hence, it is important to include material properties while analyzing the track property. Hann et al. [16] incorporated the effect of the material properties and suggested that the weld profiles in the laser welding are related to the peak enthalpy of the weld pool.

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In-part-7
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In.md
content: In this study, EOS M270 is used to fabricate the IN625 single-track samples and investigate the effect of linear energy density (LED) on the track property and porosity. A micro-CT scanner is utilized to evaluate the pores formed with different LEDs. Besides, the samples are sectioned, polished, and etched to reveal the melt pool boundary. The effect of LED on the melt pool boundary and the transition of the melting mode with the change in LED is observed. Also, the effect of power and speed on the melt pool depth is studied by keeping the LED constant at $0 . 4 8 ~ \mathrm { J / m m }$ and $0 . 7 5 \mathrm { J / m m }$ . Again, microCT is used to characterize the pores, and metallography is performed to reveal the melt pool boundary. Moreover, the normalized enthalpy is utilized to characterize the transition of the melt pool from the conduction mode to the keyhole mode. Further, the powder scale numerical model is used to investigate the heat transfer and melt flow behavior at different power and speed combinations from the same LED. A small-scale model is developed to understand the underlying physics behind the change of melting mode from conduction to keyhole.

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In-part-8
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In.md
content:
Figure 1 presents the hollow cylinder sample design used to contain the single tracks. During the X-ray imaging, it is necessary to ensure adequate X-ray transmission $1 3 0 \mathrm { k V }$ source) through the sample. As the density of IN625 $( 8 4 4 0 ~ \mathrm { k g } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 3 } )$ ) is high, the diameter of $3 \ \mathrm { m m }$ is used in this study to allow proper transmission. Figure $^ \textrm { \scriptsize 1 b }$ shows the arrangement of $1 2 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ long single tracks, which are formed between the notches. The notches work as a reference and is used to locate the tracks during the CT scanning. The tracks are formed with a $0 . 7 \mathrm { m m }$ gap as Matthews et al. [17] showed that there is a significant powder depletion around the single tracks in the SLM process. EOS M270 is used to fabricate the samples with $4 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ layer thickness in this study. The tracks are formed with the user parameters, while the hollow cylinder is fabricated using EOS M270 GP1 parameters (195 W laser power, $7 5 0 \mathrm { m m } / \mathrm { s }$ scan speed, and $1 2 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ hatch spacing). The sample is fabricated in the positive Z-direction, as shown in Fig. 1b. The hollow region is filled with IN625 powder particles due to the nature of the process, which remains contained inside the cylinder after fabrication.

Linear energy density (LED) is the ratio of laser power and scan speed,

$$
L E D \left( { \frac { J } { m m } } \right) = { \frac { P \left( W \right) } { \nu \left( { \frac { m m } { s } } \right) } } .
$$

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In-part-9
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In.md
content:
The laser power, scan speed, and the corresponding LEDs used in this study are listed in Table 1. In this study, the scan speeds from 200 to $1 2 0 0 \mathrm { m m / s }$ are used for a constant power of 195 W, while the constant speed of $2 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m / s }$ is used for power ranging from 105 to $1 9 5 \mathrm { ~ W ~ }$ . This design resulted in twelve LEDs ranging from 0.16 to $0 . 9 8 \mathrm { ~ J } / \mathrm { m m }$ . Besides obtaining the porosity at different LEDs, it is desired to observe the variation in the melt pool with the change in speed at constant power and change of power at a constant speed. Hence, metallography is performed to reveal the melt pool boundary.

![](images/4f6312548f232eb9762a2a066a201a75d0f638390f49f4fa75459a683bb0c378.jpg)  
Fig. 1 a Design and dimension of cylinder sample (units in mm) and b arrangement of the single tracks inside the cylinder sample

Ti-6Al-4 V single-track experiment performed by Shrestha et al. [13] showed that the power has more effect on porosity than the scan speed in the SLM process. However, the effect of parameters on the melt pool boundary was not studied. In this study, an experiment is designed for IN625 to study the change in the melt pool depth and porosity with different levels of power and speed. The LEDs and the respective laser power and scan speeds are listed in Table 2 and Table 3. The LED from conduction mode $\left( 0 . 4 8 \mathrm { \ J / m m } \right)$ and keyhole mode $\mathrm { 0 . 7 5 ~ J / m m ) }$ are selected to analyze the effect of the power and speed on the porosity. In addition, metallography is performed to reveal the melt pool boundary of the IN625 tracks. The transverse and longitudinal melt pool boundary is obtained, and the effect of power and speed within the same LED on the melt profile characteristics is investigated.

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In-part-10
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In.md
content: Figure 2 a shows the cylinder samples attached to the build platform through the block support. The cylinder samples were detached from the base plate, and the excess support attached to the sample surface was removed by polishing. Bruker SkyScan 1173 micro-CT scanner, which is shown in Fig. 2b, was then used to scan the cylinder samples with $6 ~  { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ pixel size at $2 \textrm { K }$ magnification. The rotation step of $0 . 2 ^ { \circ }$ was used, and $3 6 0 ^ { \circ }$ scanning was performed to obtain 1800 raw images. The raw images were reconstructed using standard reconstruction procedures, which are described in literature [13], and finally analyzed. After the CT scanning is completed, the samples were sectioned, polished, and etched to reveal the transverse melt pool boundary. The optical microscope is used to observe the melt pool boundary, and the width and depth of the single tracks are measured. The shape of the melt pool boundary is used to separate between the conduction mode and keyhole mode melting.

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In-part-11
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In.md
content:
FLOW-3D commercial software is used to develop a powder scale numerical model. An open source discrete element method (DEM) package is used to simulate the spreading of the IN625 powder layer and the powder layer is imported to the FLOW-3D software to perform the thermo-fluid simulation [18]. Figure 3 shows the simulation domain used in this study. The dimension of the solid substrate is $5 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } \times$ $3 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } \times 2 5 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } .$ , and a layer of powder is defined on top of the solid substrate. The short scan length simulation is performed to analyze the variation in temperature distribution and laser penetration at a different level of power and scan speed. The melting may not reach the steady state in the short length simulation; however, the depth of the melt pool and melting mode can be predicted as the transient region formation mostly affected the width and height [18]. Hence, the scan length of $2 5 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ is used, which is sufficient to capture the change in the temperature and the formation of the keyhole, as shown by Shrestha and Chou [11]. name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In-part-14
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In.md
content:
The CT scanned cylinder samples are analyzed to obtain the pore number and pore volume formed inside the single tracks. Figure 5 a shows the 3D image of a typical cylinder sample obtained after the CT image reconstruction. The grayscale image is based on the density of the sample. The light gray region is the solid In625, dark gray contained inside the cylinder is the In625 powder, and the black region represents the void. A transverse section of the sample is shown in Fig. 5b. Three tracks are identified based on the surface profile, and one of the tracks shows the formation of the pore inside the track. Besides, the density-based transfer function is modified to remove the powder material inside, and the 3D clipping is performed to observe the single track formed over the base, as shown in Fig. 5c. This feature enables the comparison of the surface morphologies formed with different laser parameters. Figure 6 presents the micro-CT image of the keyhole pores formed with $0 . 9 8 ~ \mathrm { J / m m }$ LED along the scan direction. The higher LED resulted in deep penetration melting. Hence, the pores are formed deep inside the track. However, the depth of the single track is not known from micro-CT, although the formation of the pore is apparent. Figure 6 also shows the 3D-rendered pores, which show that the pores formed are mostly spherical. Table 4 In625 material properties used in the numerical simulation

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In-part-15
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In.md
content:
The pores formed inside the single tracks are measured, and Fig. 7 presents the average pore quantities from three replicates for all the investigated LEDs. The error bar indicates the standard deviation from three replicates of the single tracks. In general, the single-track porosity increased with the increase in LED, and the maximum porosity is observed at the LED of $0 . 9 0 \mathrm { J / m m }$ . The increase in porosity is related to the formation of the keyhole due to the increase in energy density. However, the highest LED of $0 . 9 8 ~ \mathrm { J / m m }$ resulted in a lower average pore number and volume compared to $0 . 9 0 { } \mathrm { J } / { }$ mm.

![](images/b7ed0394ddddb7a3d2808d5bdd3d6321b0d943f3a21bc5e6c68a1dce1765f431.jpg)  
Fig. 5 a CT-scanned cylinder after reconstruction, b transverse cross section, and c modification of the transfer function to remove the powder particles and observe the single tracks

It is also noted that the number of pores formed with the same LEDs are smaller for IN625 with $4 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ layer thickness compared to the Ti-6Al-4 V experiment with $3 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ layer thickness performed by Shrestha et al. [13]. The data analytical study showed that the small variation in the layer thickness has minimal effect on the melt pool depth [9]. Hence, such a difference in the pore number and pore volume may be due to the difference in the thermal properties between the two materials. This difference in the melt pool characteristics between different materials shows the importance of including the material properties while establishing the relationship between energy density and melting modes.

![](images/0d0d24ceaa76204ce4e3d2df3aa8f97b7035f0926b04d96970cafb0e126aebc2.jpg)  
Fig. 6 2D and 3D pores formed with keyhole parameters (195 W and $2 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / \mathrm { s }$ )

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In-part-16
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In.md
content:
The pore diameter and depth are also a function of LED. The average depth of and the standard deviation of the keyhole pores formed at different LEDs are shown in Fig. 8. The pore depth increased with the increase in LED, which may be due to the increase in keyhole depth formed with increasing LEDs. Besides, the average pore size also increased with an increase in LED. The increase in the size may be related to the size of the vapor opening, which is bigger at higher LED.

The pore depth measurements suggested that deeper melt pools are formed with higher LEDs. Hence, the single-track samples are cut in the middle of the track to obtain the transverse melt pool boundaries and differentiate the melting modes. The samples are polished and then etched with modified Kalling’s reagent ( $4 0 ~ \mathrm { m l }$ distilled water $+ 4 8 0 \ \mathrm { m l \ H C l + }$ $4 8 \ \mathrm { m g \ C u c l 2 }$ ) to reveal the melt pool boundary. Figure 9 shows the transverse melt pool boundary formed with different LEDs. The depth of the melt pool increased with the LED. For a constant power, the width and depth of the melt pool decreased with an increase in speed due to the decrease in the interaction time. However, for the same speed, the depth increased with power due to the increase in the laser penetration.

![](images/f5f4d3273100f6d4cb5ba09f81cac2543e9bd75b0e1e5cc8a8bb9d2702932774.jpg)  
Fig. 7 Pore volume and pore number from different LEDs

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In-part-17
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In.md
content: The melt pool dimensions of the single tracks are measured from the transverse profile. Figure 10 shows the measurement approach of the track width and depth and the relationship between LED and track width and depth. The track width and depth increased with increasing LED. However, the increase in depth is significant compared to the width. The width of the track is higher than the depth for all the conduction mode melting, while the depth is higher than the width for the deep keyhole mode melting. A second-order polynomial curve is fitted to both depth and width, which shows that the depth is increasing almost linearly with LED. However, the width of the track increased with an increase in LED within conduction mode but did not show an obvious increase within the keyhole regime. The maximum width of the track may be limited by the beam diameter and increasing the energy density with the same beam diameter may increase the depth rather than width after reaching a certain limit. There are some cases where the higher LED resulted in the shallower melt pool. The LED of $0 . 5 3 \mathrm { J / m m }$ ( $1 0 5 \mathrm { W }$ and $2 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / \mathrm { s }$ ) resulted in the depth lower than $0 . 4 9 \ \mathrm { J / m m }$ ( $\cdot 9 5 ~ \mathrm { W }$ and $4 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m / s } ,$ ). This behavior may be due to the significant difference in the power between the two LEDs. However, the LED of $0 . 9 8 \ J /$ mm (195 and $2 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / \mathrm { s }$ ) also resulted in shallower melt pool compared to the LED of $0 . 9 0 ~ \mathrm { J / m m }$ ( $1 8 0 ~ \mathrm { W }$ and $2 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m / s }$ ), although $0 . 9 8 ~ \mathrm { J / m m }$ had a higher power. Such anomaly may be due to the variation in the melt pool depth during the keyhole melting. The longitudinal metallography should be performed to obtain the variation in depth along the laser travel direction.

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In-part-19
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In.md
content: $0 . 4 8 ~ \mathrm { J / m m }$ and $0 . 7 5 ~ \mathrm { J / m m }$ LED are selected, and the average pore number, volume, and standard deviation from three replicates are shown in Fig. 11. The LED of $0 . 4 8 \mathrm { J / m m }$ resulted in fewer pores compared to the $0 . 7 5 \mathrm { J / m m }$ . Besides, the porosity increased with an increase in power for both LEDs. However, the porosity was not maximum for the highest power. The numerical study [11] showed that the formation of the keyhole pores is due to instabilities in the keyhole wall caused by the interplay between surface tension pressure and recoil pressure. Within the keyhole mode at the same energy density, the increase in power would increase the radius of the vapor opening. At a certain point, the instability between the surface tension and vapor opening leads to the formation of many pores due to the collapse of the keyhole wall. However, with further increase in the power, the keyhole opening is large enough so that the surface tension pressure is unable to close the keyhole wall, leading to a stable keyhole. This reduces the chance of the pore formation. For the same LED, the mode of melting changed from incomplete to conduction and finally to keyhole with increasing power and speed.

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In-part-20
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In.md
content: The surface morphology and the respective transverse melt profile of the single tracks formed with different levels of power and scan speed from LED of $0 . 4 8 ~ \mathrm { J / m m }$ are shown in Fig. 12. At a low power, that is $2 4 ~ \mathrm { W }$ , discontinuous track is formed. The discontinuity corresponds to the insufficient melting, which is usually the case with very low LEDs. In this case, even if the LED is high, the power is very low. Hence, the low power resulted in the lower melt pool temperature, and consequently, the laser penetration was insufficient to form a continuous single track. As the power and speed are increased, continuous tracks are formed. The melt pool depth slowly increased within the conduction modes from $4 8 \mathrm { ~ W ~ }$ and $1 0 0 \mathrm { m m / s }$ to $9 6 \mathrm { W }$ and $2 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / \mathrm { s }$ . However, there is a sudden increase in the depth when the laser power increased to $1 2 0 ~ \mathrm { W }$ , suggesting the keyhole mode melting. Figure 12 reveals a clear evolution of the melting modes from the incomplete to the conduction mode and finally to the keyhole mode melting with an increase in the laser power and scan speed at the same energy density. Although the depth of the melt pool increased with increasing power and speed, the average volume and number of pores were not maximum for the maximum speed and power used. This shows that the porosity is not directly related to the depth of the keyhole, rather its occurrence depends on the stability of the keyhole formed, during the melting process. Besides the depth of the melt pool, the width of the track also increased with an increase in the power and speed from incomplete melting to the keyhole melting. However, the track width did not show an obvious increase with the increase in power within the keyhole mode, which is consistent with the result obtained in the LED effect study discussed in the previous section.
