content:
V-shape morphology was observed on the surface of the solidifed region. This shape was formed due to the distribution of laser energy in Gaussian’s distribution form and uneven distribution of temperature which was caused by the difference between surface tension and density. The narrower edge in the V-shape morphology is indicated using arrows in Fig. 5e as the depression of the molten pool occurred at the lower end due to the maximum dispersal of laser energy at the beam centre. It led to stirring the molten pools and formed the V-shape morphology. Some of the equiaxial cell were formed in the SLM specimen in the form of unavoidable triple overlapping zone, during the SLM process (Fig. 5f). The frst layer underwent cooling during the cycle time of the deposition of this whole frst layer. During the deposition of the second layer on the frst layer, the crystal structure formed at the intersection of these two layers was diferent from the remaining region of the layers.

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-22
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: Figure $_ { 6 \mathrm { a - g } }$ shows the cross-sectional image and EDS report of the conventional and SLM processed alloys. From the elemental analysis, the conventional alloy has the element concentrations in higher fraction of $\mathrm { w t } \%$ , starting from Ni followed by Cr, C, Mo, Nb and Fe. It was formed due to the precipitation strengthening process that led to form $\mathrm { N i } _ { 3 } \mathrm { N b }$ and carbides (MC, $\mathrm { M } _ { 6 } \mathrm { C } )$ ). In the conventional alloy, there could be a possibility for oxidation between carbon and oxygen which can be eliminated in the SLM specimen by using nitrogen shroud gas atmospheric condition throughout the printing processing. Similarly, EDS analysis was performed on the three diferent structures of SLM specimen, namely columnar, equiaxial and cellular cells. The corresponding results are listed out in Table 4. In the equiaxial cell, Ni and Cr elements were more in weight fraction. This was because the solvent atoms of $\mathrm { C r }$ were higher compared to other alloying elements that led to dilution in a solid solution of $\gamma$ -Ni phases. At the cellular and columnar cell, the content of the Ni element was less compared to the equiaxial cell. In addition to that, the presence of Mo and Nb was signifcantly higher than that of the equiaxial cell. These higher (Mo, Nb) phases were usually formed at the rapid solidifcation process as the SLM process solidifed the layer very rapidly compared to other fabrication processes. Moreover, Mo and Nb elements have a tendency to segregate during the melting of the Inconel-625 powder while the SLM process was performed [26]. Mo and Nb elements moved continuously from the molten coagulation powder zone to the liquid region due to its difusion property. As a result, segregation of Mo and Nb elements occurred and increased its presence in the cellular and columnar cells region.

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-24
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: EBSD was performed on both the conventional specimens and SLM-based specimens at XY, YZ and ZX planes. The EBSD images in Fig. 7 clearly show the texture cells, orientation of both the conventional and SLM specimens. Equiaxed and columnar cells were represented as circular and rectangular dotted lines in Fig. 7. Figure 7a shows the conventional alloy at XY direction which possessed larger size cells as well as equiaxed texture morphology. These cells had grown at random directions and the size of the cells were more or less of uniform nature. All of the cells in the conventional alloy specimen had equiaxed larger size cells. Larger elongation columnar cells are observed in Fig. 7b where the length of cells is around $2 0 { - } 2 5 \mathrm { ~ m ~ }$ . In Fig.  7b, the presence of each cell is represented by a unique colour. Throughout the image in Fig. 7b, similar columnar cell is found which confrms that the columnar texture dominated during the formation of the cells in the SLM specimen. The columnar cells had grown from the bottom region to the top region of the molten pool. The interaction of the laser and Inconel-625 powder, un-melted Inconel-625 powder, liquid molten metal and shroud gas collaboratively generated the steeper temperature gradient. This temperature gradient created Marangoni convection and surface tension. The convection fow velocity of the molten pool reached $1 0 \mathrm { m / s }$ as per the results obtained from the simulation work in [27]. This convection heat transfer of the molten pool had broken the initial growth of the columnar cells. As a result, parts of columnar dendrites changed their direction of growth. Thus, the growth of the cells was seen in diferent directions and not in the same direction. Thus, the property of the material is mainly dependent on the formation of these textures. However, along with the columnar cell, some equiaxed cells, as well as the cellular cell, were found in the SLM specimen (Fig. 7b).

The cell growth in the SLM specimen was based on the higher amount of rapid heat dissipation during the solidifcation along the three directions, which caused the formation of smaller and heterogeneously columnar crystal cell [28]. These columnar cells were grown across the parallel layers in the build direction of the SLM specimen. This directional growth of columnar cell transferred heat due to rapid cooling rate along the build direction. Similar types of cells were observed in other planes such as YZ and ZX. The equiaxed cell was observed in the conventional alloyed specimen at YZ and ZX in Fig. 7c and e, respectively. Similarly, columnar cell, some equiaxed and cellular cells are observed in the YZ (Fig. 7d) and ZX (Fig. 7f) planes of the SLM specimen. The remelted region where the equiaxed cell was grown inbetween the adjacent molten pools and the size of the cells were observed to be under $2 \mathrm { - } 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ . In addition, the orientation of the cells was observed at a diferent angle.

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-26
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: Triple overlap melted region gave rise to the equiaxed cell whereas double overlap melted region generated the cellular cell. This trend was clearly observed across the building direction of the specimen, which was actually dependent on the heat fow during the SLM process. It indicated that recrystallization had occurred between the layers. The subsequent columnar cells were grown after recrystallization and yielded heterogeneous microstructure and formed strong cells orientation texture. The cells in all three directions such as building direction, scanning direction and stepover direction were in the length size between 20 and $2 5 \mathrm { ~ m ~ }$ . Wang $\textsf { Z }$ et al. [29] studied the behaviour of columnar cells with respect to wear resistance and found that the columnar cells provide the path way to defect the crack propagation. This phenomenon modifed the growth of crack and enhance the fracture resistance by modifying the microstructural formation. Similar observations were observed in the present study in which the SLM specimen has columnar cells that may be helpful to enhance its wear resistance.

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-27
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: Hardness is an important infuential property to specify the material strength according to the strength of the bonding between each layer interface and atomic joining of single layer atoms. The nano-indentation test was performed on a cross-sectional surface under the load of $2 2 0 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { N }$ to examine the hardness of the conventional and SLM-based Inconel-625 specimen. Figure 8 shows the indentation print and indentation depth profle of the conventional (Fig. 8a) and SLM specimens (Fig. 8b). The average hardness measured by indentations was taken appropriately at three random points on the specimen surface. Moreover, the conventional alloy specimen underwent a $1 3 0 \mathrm { n m }$ depth of indentation at $2 2 0 0 \mu \mathrm { N }$ load condition, whereas the SLM specimen reached only $7 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ . It shows that the SLM specimen had a nearly $4 6 \%$ reduction in the indentation depth. Figure 8c revealed that the nano-hardness distribution of the SLM specimen was nearly uniform whereas more fuctuated values were observed in the conventional alloy specimen. It indicated that the SLM specimen possessed a uniform columnar cell in most of the region. The measured average nano-hardness for SLM and conventional alloy specimens are $6 . 0 2 \mathrm { G P a }$ and $4 . 8 8 \mathrm { G P a }$ , respectively. Comparing to the conventional alloy specimens, the SLM-produced specimen exhibited higher nano-hardness. The conventional alloy specimen possessed a larger cell (Fig. 5a) than the SLM specimen (Fig. 5b–d) which was responsible for the decreased hardness.

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-28
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: The enhancement of hardness of the SLM specimen was due to the microstructural modifcations and rapid heat dissipation during the phase changes which developed an efective bonding between the layers in the SLM technique. Moreover, in the SLM specimen, the alloying elements such as the Cr solute atom were well diluted in the solid solution of Ni solvent that led to an increase in the hardness of the SLM processed specimen. The involvement in the rapid heating and cooling rate of the SLM process produced the internal residual stress and twining, and this caused enhancement in hardness. Moreover, the decrease of the cell size due to a larger temperature gradient and increase in the lattice distortion values were also responsible for the increase of the nano-hardness value. The increase in the lattice parameter was due to the dissolution of Cr elements into the Ni matrix. Nano-hardness of the SLM specimen was comparable to the literature data that was produced by the EBM process due to larger temperature gradients in SLM than that of EBM as the powder bed was preheated to $1 0 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ in the EBM process [30]. Moreover, the columnar cells restricted the boundary movement due to dislocation, which resulted in the improvement of the hardness of the SLM specimen. In the SLM process, molten Inconel-625 powder was deposited layerby-layer and the specimen was fabricated from the bottom layer to the top layer. During this process, the Inconel-625 powder deposited as the newest layer was bonded with the previous layer through thermal conductivity. As a result, the new layer transferred heat energy to the previously solidifed layer which was repeated until a full specimen was fabricated. It led to form second phase crystal structures such as equiaxed and cellular cell. However, because of lack of time and transfer of heat energy during the SLM process, these second phase crystal structure formations were fewer.

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-29
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content:
Hence, small size columnar crystal and superior heat transfer property led to retain this structure even though there was heat transfer from the top surface to the bottom surface during the SLM process. As a result, equiaxed and cellular cells were present only in a small region. Hence, the lack of structural change led to retain the nano-hardness uniform throughout the region.

![](images/135133fe43251a7ece0ba1500ae1c7777a9855cfd44f99ecf7194a284e0f868d.jpg)

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-30
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: The dry sliding wear test was performed on both the conventional Inconel-625 alloy and the SLM Inconel-625 specimens, and the values for wear rate and coefcient of friction (CoF) were obtained for the tested specimens. The results depended on various tribological process parameters such as applied load, sliding velocity, operating temperature, etc. [31]. The applied load $5 0 ~ \mathrm { N }$ , sliding velocity $1 . 2 ~ \mathrm { m / s }$ and sliding distance $2 8 0 0 \mathrm { ~ m ~ }$ were selected as processing parameters for the present wear study. The wear rate and CoF of both the specimens are shown in Fig.  9. It was observed that the wear rate of the conventional Inconel-625 alloy specimen exhibited higher value compared with the SLM specimen as shown in Fig. 9a. The wear rate of the conventional Inconel-625 alloy specimen shows around $4 . 5 8 \times 1 0 ^ { - 3 } \ \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } / \mathrm { m }$ , while the SLM specimen showed $1 . 8 3 \times 1 0 ^ { - 3 } \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } / \mathrm { m } .$ . Initially, the wear rate for the conventional Inconel-625 alloy specimen was the same as the SLM specimen up to $4 0 \mathrm { s }$ sliding rotation. However, the wear rate started to increase in the conventional Inconel-625 alloy specimens after $4 0 \mathrm { s }$ sliding rotation. The SLM specimen is controlled by the wear rate and maintained as constant for the complete sliding distance of $2 8 0 0 \mathrm { m }$ . The SLM-produced specimen showed higher hardness and a comparatively reduced wear rate compared to the conventional Inconel-625 alloy specimen. The higher wear rate of the conventional Inconel-625 alloy specimen is due to the reduced hardness. The columnar cells with smaller size and good bonding strength between the layers enhanced the wear resistance of the SLM specimen.

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-31
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content:
Also, the $\gamma$ -Ni solid solution phase of SLM with a small amount of strengthening elements such as Nb, Mo and carbides formations enabled defect-free surface and enhanced the hardness, which improved the material strength to resist the friction and lowered the material loss. Besides, the conventional Inconel-625 alloy specimen showed higher material loss due to its greater cell size and reduced hardness.

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-32
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: The CoF of the conventional Inconel-625 alloy and SLM Inconel-625 specimen are shown in Fig. 9b. The CoF of the conventional Inconel-625 alloy specimen is increased drastically to 0.45 and then gradually the slop of CoF was increased to $3 5 0 ~ \mathrm { s }$ . In these regions, those contact areas started to progress into the self-mating stage which is produced in contact with the higher region between the pin and disc. Then, the CoF abruptly changed from 350 s to the end of the experiment due to the considerable friction generated between the pin and the disc. Hence, the frictional force was increased and accordingly, the CoF also was increased. The SLM produced specimen shows lesser CoF, approximately 0.2, compared with the conventional Inconel-625 alloy specimen. This reduced CoF was expected due to more hardness of the surface which is produced through the SLM process [32, 33]. The increased strength on the SLM surface was initiated the less contact on the counterpart. Moreover, the contact points had higher hardness and had more shear strength. Hence, it needed more energy to shear the surfaces of the SLM specimen [34]. In this situation, heat was produced due to the frictional force and while increasing the heat between the sliding surfaces, there is a possibility to form the oxide layer on the pin surface. These oxide layers reduced the friction further as well as minimized the wear rate in the SLM specimen [35].

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-33
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: The tribological properties of materials against friction and involvement of diferent wear mechanisms are majorly dependent on their material hardness and grain orientation. Thus, rearrangement of atoms and grain size reduction have a good agreement with the improvement of hardness stands on important mechanical property of the material. The wornout surfaces of the conventional Inconel-625 alloy and SLM Inconel-625 specimens are shown in Fig. 10a and b. It can be observed that the conventional Inconel-625 alloy specimen was afected severely and it lost more material due to heavy wear on its surface. Abrasion, cracks, pits, delamination, discontinuous deep grooves and wear debris were found on it. In the conventional Inconel-625 alloy specimen, the worn-out surface had shown scattered deep grooves and furrows which clearly represented the occurrence of abrasive wear. The micro abrasion was considered by microstructural variations, strengthening phase distributions and amount of alloying elements fraction. The conventional Inconel-625 alloy specimen showed more micro abrasion while the SLM specimen had shown mild abrasion which is observed in Fig. 10a and b. Some small plate-like wear debris, micro pits and cracks were observed over the surface on the conventional Inconel-625 specimen which demonstrates the presence of deformation phenomenon and delamination wear on the worn-out surface. This delamination led to plastic distortion, crack initiation, propagation and further extended to layer-by-layer delamination [36]. It can be noted that deep wear tracks and more deformed areas were observed on the conventional Inconel-625 specimens compared to the SLM processed samples. Figure 10c shows the EDS results obtained for the conventional Inconel-625 specimens after the wear test.

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-34
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content:
![](images/f125da6eb3ee510fa8e8251fd50748a4c4047b955777e553734a11cdd894417c.jpg) Fig. 10 Worn out surface micrograph of Inconel-625 superalloy: a as-cast specimen b SLM specimen EDS result of worn out surface of Inconel-625 superalloy: c as-cast specimen d SLM specimen On the other hand, the worn-out surface of the SLM specimen (Fig. 10b) showed mild abrasion and less deformed areas. This was due to the improved stability of resisting friction under long sliding distances and high loads. The observed CoF for the SLM specimen was around 0.2 which got much reduced due to the efective solid solution strengthening efect of Nb and Mo in the nickel phase. The motion of hard materials such as nickel alloy against the hardened-steel was increasing the local temperature. During the dry sliding test, the higher hardness of the SLM specimen reduced the material removal by increasing the abrasion resistance which would prevent the contact surface wear. In addition, the indication of cracks and delamination were obtained due to the plowing efect. Further, the EDS analysis results (Table 5) of the SLM worn-out specimen showed higher oxide formation $( 7 . 3 9 \% )$ compared with the conventional Inconel-625 $( 1 . 8 6 \% )$ worn-out specimen. Hence, oxide formation also reduces the wear rate on the SLMproduced surfaces. The EDS results for the SLM specimen after the wear test are shown in Fig. 10d. ![](images/14b033cbebc780530275376741e468cb0467a161020aa27d73d02eafc9e3b86a.jpg) Fig. 10 (continued) Table 5 EDS analysis results of worn surface of Conventional alloy specimen and SLM specimens

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-35
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content:
![](images/e3a4854ca1f58f81079c18c1bf22f28b7c9cb089954048d8afd4a4d9b1fc60d5.jpg)  
Fig.11 Schematic representation of wear mechanism of Inconel-625 material: a Conventional alloy specimen, b SLM specimen

The relation between the microstructure of the conventional Inconel-625 alloy and SLM Inconel-625 specimen with their wear mechanism is schematically represented in Fig. 11. The wear rate of the specimens is dependent on the ability to resist the slippage of material. During the wear test, the material deformation occurred due to nucleation of dislocation on the slip plane. The dislocation and plastic deformation increased as the motion of the specimen moved continuously on the disc surface under particular load conditions. In the present study, $5 0 \mathrm { N }$ load was applied on the specimen against the disc surface while the specimen was rotating on the disc surface. The normal force of $5 0 \mathrm { N }$ was acting in the negative direction of $\mathbf { Z }$ , while the friction force was acting at the x and y directions, which is represented in Fig. 11. Slippage of the plane has occurred when the shear force exceeded the maximum wear resistance of the material which is dependent on the orientation of grain growth as well as grain size. A larger grain size of equiaxed Inconel-625 (Fig. 11a) would easily slip compared to smaller grain. Similarly, larger size uniform equiaxed grain structure and columnar grains arrangement (Fig. 11b) in the same direction are prone to large slippage compared to columnar grains arrangement at an angle which had exposed less shear force than the conventional equiaxed Inconel-625 specimen. Moreover, columnar grains arrangement at an angle had resisted the slip of the plane as the SLM Inconel-625 specimen possessed an inclined columnar grain structure.

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-36
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: Studied the wear behaviour of $3 1 6 \mathrm { L }$ stainless steel based on grain orientation [37]. It was found that the orientation of grains infuenced the generation of shear force which would act on the slip plane and concluded that the grains oriented at a steeper angle faced more shear force than those arranged at a moderate angle. In addition, the columnar dendrite structure easily adapted to the stain changes during the dry sliding wear test when compared to the equiaxed structure. The columnar dendrite structure coped up with the shear force which was induced during the wear test, whereas the equiaxed structure peeled of from the surface due to more shear force acting on it. It led to the removal of more material from the conventional alloyed surface in the form of abrasive groove, micro crater and pits, as the conventional alloyed specimen had a large size equiaxed structure (Fig. 10a). On the other hand, the columnar structure also peeled of; but the process took place gradually when the shear force acted on the columnar structure, and the peeling of was less compared to the conventional alloy at the same load condition due to angular orientation of the columnar structure and fne grain structure. Moreover, the SLM Inconel-625 specimen had some equiaxed structure and grains in random direction due to dissipation of heat fow during the SLM process based on material evaporation, gas expansion [38] and Marangoni fow [39]. As a result, some micro cracks and crates were observed on the SLM specimen, as it had a major quantity of columnar structure. As a result, the conventional alloy surface had a large quantity of the loss of equiaxed structure that led to increased surface roughness. On the contrary, a smooth worn-out surface was formed on the SLM specimen.

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-38
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: The average roughness of worn-out surfaces was measured by using the white light interferometer. The 3-dimensional topography and average roughness graph of the worn-out conventional Inconel-625 and SLM specimens are shown in Fig. 12. The measured average roughness was $4 . 9 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ for the conventional Inconel-625 specimens. However, the SLM worn-out specimen showed an average roughness of $2 . 1 4 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ . The higher wear rate and the reduced hardness directly refected on the roughness of the worn-out surface for the conventional Inconel-625 specimen [40]. The conventional Inconel-625 specimen showed a higher roughness average compared with the SLM worn-out specimen. The worn-out 3D topography of the conventional Inconel-625 specimen (Fig. 12a) shows higher valleys and peaks because of reduced hardness and higher material loss. As an outcome, the conventional Inconel-625 surface was damaged severely and formed the rough surface (Fig.  12b) with higher roughness. Therefore, the surface topography was afected heavily because of higher frictional force between the sliding surface, which leads to minimizing the service life of the component. However, the worn-out surface of the SLM specimen showed lesser variations in the valleys and peaks (Fig. 12c) due to the minimized wear rate. Therefore, the worn-out surface produced a lower roughness average (Fig. 12d) compared with the conventional Inconel-625 specimen.

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-39
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content:
This study used the SLM process to fabricate the Inconel-625 superalloy and compared its properties such as phase evolution, microstructural features and nano-hardness with the conventionally produced Inconel-625 superalloy. Further, the tribological behaviour of SLM produced Inconel-625 and conventional Inconel-625 superalloy were studied and plausible wear mechanisms were analysed. Based on this study, the following conclusions are derived.

• The SLM specimen has more intensity at (111) difraction peak than the other two specimens and revealed that the solid solution of $\gamma$ -(Ni, Cr, Fe) (FCC) phases are grown at (111), (2 0 0) and (220) planes.   
The Inconel-625 powder has lattice parameters of $0 . 3 5 9 2 { \mathrm { n m } }$ , $0 . 3 1 1 6 \mathrm { n m }$ and $0 . 3 0 1 2 \mathrm { n m }$ , whereas the SLM specimen possessed the lattice parameters of $0 . 3 5 9 9 { \mathrm { n m } }$ , $0 . 3 1 2 1 ~ \mathrm { { n m } }$ and $0 . 3 0 1 2 ~ \mathrm { n m }$ which were higher than the other two specimens.   
Discontinuous boundary region, shrinkage cavity and crack formed during the SLM process at $2 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ power, $1 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ beam spot size with the scanning speed of $9 2 5 \mathrm { m m / s }$ .   
. A defect-free surface was formed on the SLM specimen at $3 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ power, $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ beam spot size with the scanning speed of $9 2 5 \mathrm { m m / s }$ , which produced three diferent cells namely columnar, equiaxial and cellular cells, out of which, the columnar cell has grown in most of the regions of the SLM specimen. The EBSD revealed that

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-40

content:
the distribution of -phases were maximum and, equiaxed columnar cells were observed.

The conventional alloy specimen underwent a $1 3 0 ~ \mathrm { { n m } }$ depth of indentation at $2 2 0 0 \mu \mathrm { N }$ load condition, whereas the SLM specimen reached only $7 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ . It shows that the SLM specimen had a nearly $4 6 \%$ reduction in the indentation depth. The measured average nano-hardness for SLM and conventional alloy specimens are 6.02 GPa and $4 . 8 8 \ : \mathrm { G P a }$ , respectively. Comparing to the conventional alloy specimens, the SLM-produced specimen exhibited higher nano-hardness due to fne micro-columnar cell and solid solution strengthening.

• The wear rate of the conventional Inconel-625 alloy specimen was around $4 . 5 8 \times 1 0 ^ { - 3 } \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } / \mathrm { m }$ while the SLM specimen showed $1 . 8 3 \times 1 0 ^ { - 3 } \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } / \mathrm { m }$ at the applied load of $5 0 \mathrm { N }$ , sliding velocity of $1 . 2 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s }$ and sliding distance of $2 8 0 0 \mathrm { m }$ .

Equiaxed cell of the conventional Inconel-625 alloy specimen peeled of from the surface due to more shear force acting on it. It led to the removal of more material from the conventional alloyed surface in the form of abrasive groove, micro crater and pits, as the conventional alloyed specimen had large size equiaxed cell.

SLM specimen possessed angular columnar cell which also peeled of but the process took place gradually, as the shear force acting on the angular columnar cell was less than that of the conventional Inconel-625 alloy specimen.

• The measured roughness was $4 . 9 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ for the conventional Inconel-625 specimen, whereas the SLM wornout specimen showed an average roughness of $2 . 1 4 \mu \mathrm { m }$ , as it had fewer peaks and valleys. Thus, the SLM technique is a promising and predominant one to develop nickel-based superalloys for frictional applications.

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-1
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content:
Research paper

# Numerical investigation of baling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 718
C. Zoller a,\*, N.A. Adams a,b, S. Adami a,b

aTechnical Universityofunich,ScholofngeringndDesign,ChairoferodyamicsndFluidechnicsBoltzmte 15,85748 Garching, Germany bTechnicaUifcceedeldossb

# ARTICLEINFO


# ABSTRACT
Keywords:   
Smoothed particle hydrodynamics   
SPH   
Balling   
Process map   
Single melt track defect   
Powder bed fusion   
Selective laser melting

Balling is one of the main single melt track defects limiting stable production of dense parts with laserbased powder bed fusion of metals (PBF-LB/M) additive manufacturing.A fundamental understanding of balling therefore is critical for process control and optimization.Violent interface dynamics present a severe challenge for mesh-based numerical schemes,and can be dealt with by particle methods.In this study, we focus on investigating single melt tracks by smoothed particle hydrodynamics (SPH).The considered regime is characterized by long liquid melt pools and remelting of the previous layer.The balling mechanism is driven by Marangoni and capillary forces.The resulting convective melt flux leads to the accumulation of melt in the tail region and leaves an exposed area of marginal layer build-up.In addition to the competing mechanisms of solidification and spreading,a competition between spreading and melt contraction shortly after the melt pinch-offis observed.We find a similarballng behavior yet diferent ball size at different laser power setings. We stress that SPH with accurate interface modeling has the capability to quantify balling processes and to improve the understanding of balling mechanisms.
summary: Numerical investigation of baling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 718 前言

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-2
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content:
Laser-based powder bed fusion is becoming an increasingly competitive manufacturing technique.A high energy laser beam is applied to selectively melt powder particles within a powder bed.The molten particles coalesce to form a melt pool that subsequently fuses and consolidates with the previous layer of material.With an appropriate selection of process parameters a successive layer-by-layer buildup allows for the fabrication of dense parts with high design flexibility, for instance,by enabling complex part production down to the micro scale and tailored material properties.Powder bed fusionis applied to a variety of materials such as alloys [1,2],ceramics [3] and polymers [4] and is also utilized in the development of new material composites [5,6].Hence,laser-based powder bed fusion is a promising addition to established formative and substractive manufacturing approaches.

The fundamental building unit in laser-based powder bed fusion is the single melt track since each manufactured layer is composed of consecutive single tracks.Manufacturing defects of final parts often originate from melt-flow instabilities during single track formation. It is important to understand the defect generation in single track melt pools and their dependence on process parameters.Much effort has been dedicated to identify process maps that lead to stable single melt tracks [7-9],where a known process map constraint is due to melt pool balling.

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-3
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content: Balling describes the breakup of continuous melt pools into melt agglomerates.The process is also referred to as 'aggregation of melt islands'or‘humps'[1O,11].It is found to occur in melt tracks of quite different materials such as aluminum [12],titanium [9],nickel [13], and steel [14] alloys.As balling is observed at high laser scan speeds in combination with both high [15] and low [1O] laser power,as well as low laser scan speeds and high laser power [l6],it is considered as one of the key defect mechanisms [1]. Large-size balling can cause a non-uniform powder distribution in the consecutive powder layer, poor wettability of the previous layer [2,3],pore formation [14],and even an interruption of the build process due to a collision with the paving roller [14]. Final parts show a rough surface morphology [14], higher porosity [15] or poor inter layer bonding [17] around balls.

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-4
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content: Several factors are identified to affect balling in single track melt pools.In general, balling occurs due to a minimization of the surface free energy by capillary forces.The overall intensity of capillary forces depends on melt temperature as,for many materials,surface tension decreases with increasing temperature. Consequently,Marangoni flow induced by high temperature gradients at the melt pool surface contributes to the breakup of continuous tracks [18]. Balling is further driven by poor wettability between the liquid metal and its surrounding powder particles and substrate [12,16,17,19]. Insuficient remelting of the previous layer is particularly problematic when oxide layers are formed on the substrate, as they increase the wetting angles between the liquid and solid material [2O]. Sufficient remelting therefore is important to destroy such oxide layers [21] as well. Additionally,oxidation can invert surface tension gradients leading to surface flows directed towards the melt pool center and thus support melt aggregation [6].At low power density settings balling can occur in the form of melt island-aggregates.Insufficient heating leads to partially melted particles，unmelted substrate beneath the powder, and a melt pool that tends to cluster rather than wet the surface [22,23].Low melt temperatures and thus high melt viscosity and surface tension further enhance the process [1,5,14]. A commonly suggested solution to avoid such events is to increase the energy input [1] or reduce the powder layer thickness [9].At high scan velocities, the melt pool width and thus the weted substrate area decreases [24]. Long and narrow melt pools are prone to the Plateau-Rayleigh instability [2,3,7,10,13,15-18,24-26]. Poor melt pool spreading and shallow melt pool penetration further enhance the pool instability and breakup [7,12,14].

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-5
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content:
Analytical stability models [7,11,21,27] are used as breakup conditions for continuous single melt tracks [12,28-3O],yet their ability to predict the onset of balling is still in question [31].As the melt-pool-length-to-diameter ratio increases with increasing laser scan velocity,the melt pool is particularly susceptible to Plateau-Rayleigh instabilities in the process window of high scan speed and high laser power [24]. Ball formation also is found at low scan speeds and high energy input. High energy content within the melt pool reduces the rate of solidification.Hence,the time scale at which surface tension affects pool breakup increases as well [3O]. This type of balling at large liquid formation is referred to as 'self balling'[16,32].Ball formation itself is identified as a competitive non-equilibrium process between melt spreading and solidification [8,33,34]. Final droplet shapes depend on the complex interplay of capillary forces,inertia,solidification,thermal properties and heat content [33].While balling is avoided when the melt can spread out before it solidifies,quick cooling rates lead to premature termination of spreading and enhance balling [8].

Extensive research is required to better understand the multitude of simultaneous mechanisms and to identify and enhance process maps for stable production.Process complexity in combination with temporal and spatial scales at the micro level make experimental in-situ measurements infeasible.Hence,increasing attention is devoted to numerical investigations [3,9,16,17,22,25,35-37].An adequate representation of selective laser melting at the powder scale,however,requires comprehensive numerical modeling.Its multi-phase nature in combination with phase transitions and complex interface topologies with strong deformations pose severe challenges to the underlying algorithms.

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-6
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content: Yet, several numerical studies are able to reproduce the balling phenomenon and allow for an in-depth analysis of the melt-pool breakup process.Ren et al.[22] apply the finite volume method in combination with a volume-of-fluid interface algorithm and ray-tracing laser model to study the absorptive behavior and flow kinetics of a copper alloy. Their single melt track study shows intense absorptivity oscillations, which are ascribed to balling and result in increased exposure of substrate rather than melt to the laser beam.Adiscrete element method including viscous coalescence and densification models has been used for the study of balling phenomena of a nickel alloy by Boutaous et al.[35].Large variations of melt track widths indicate the presence of balling.From a sensitivity study on surface tension and viscosity they conclude that neither of the two have a significant influence on balling as coalescence of the melt is too fast. Li et al.[17] apply a phase-field method to 2D simulations of single melt tracks for pure nickel powder on stainless steel substrate.Their study of various wetting conditions between melt and substrate reveals a decreasing frequency of melt pool breakup for low wetting angles.Single melt track simulations of 316L stainless steel show discontinuous tracks and melt agglomeration at partially melted powder particles [36].The finite volume method algorithm by Gu et al.[37] is coupled with the volume of fluid interface model to study melt pool behavior in multi-layer scenarios.They show that the melt track of the first layer is discontinuous and exhibits melt agglomerates.A subsequent second layer leads to further clustering of melt and lack of fusion between the two layers.While at an increased power density a wavy but continuous first melt track is formed,in the second layer balling still occurs.It is concluded that the surface morphology of the first layer contributes to balling of consecutive layers.

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-7
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content: Single melt tracks of AlSiloMg are investigated by Yu etal.[16] with a finite volume algorithm and volume of fluid interface treatment. They find melt pool breakup at high power densities.A detailed analysis of heating,melting and coalescing process of two powder particles reveals a flow pattern dominated by buoyancy and capillary forces.In [3], Moniz et al.applya finite element method and the level-set interface method to study laser beam melting of Al2O3 oxide ceramics.They find the frequency of balling to increase with a reduction of power densities.They point out the lack of layer build up between balls due to the melt agglomeration.Balling of single melt tracks of titanium alloy Ti6Al4V is investigated by Yan etal.[9].The results show partial melting of powder particles and a lack of substrate melting. The study of different powder setups reveals an independence of balling from the random powder packing,yet a strong dependence on the powder size distribution and powder layer thickness.

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-8
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content: Most numerical research on balling processes is focused on balling ina regime characterized by low power densities,partially melted powder particles and small melt pools.Results show only slight or no melting of the substrate [10,l6,17,22].In this regime the low amount of melt commonly is given as reason for melt pool balling [1,3,16,36,37].However, balling also occurs when there is full powderand considerable substrate-melting [38].Yet,a detailed numerical study of balling in this important part of the process map still is missing from literature.A material of particular interest for aerospace applications is the Inconel 718 nickel-based superalloy.Like many other alloys,the process map suffers from limitations in process parameter choice due to balling.Both,analytically [28] and experimentally [38] estimated power-scan-speed process maps including a balling threshold are available in literature. Only few numerical studies on balling can be found,none of which focuses on the analysis of driving forces of balling.Additionally,the majority of numerical research into balling is conducted with mesh based methods such as finite volume or finite element methods.

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-9
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content: The aim of this work is to close the gap of balling research in the regime defined by a fully melted powder bed and considerable substrate remelting.We focus on the contribution of driving forces on the breakup mechanism and the ball formation in this regime.Thus, the research into balling of Inconel 718 melt tracks is extended by a more quantitative comparison of forces.To that end,we conduct several single melt track simulations at different laser power and laser scan speed settings.First,the simulation results are validated by comparison of melt pool depth and width with experimental data.Then, we focus on the balling process and compare simulation results at process parameter sets both with the presence and absence of balling to analytical and experimental references followed by an analysis of the underlying physical mechanisms.We also demonstrate the capability of smoothed particle hydrodynamics (SPH) to resolve such complex multi-phase phenomena,which to the best of our knowledge,has not been previously applied to the problem of balling in laser powder bed fusion.The remainder of this work is as follows:In section two,the physical model is introduced,relevant simplifications are stated and the numerical setup is described.Simulation results are shown and discussed in section three.Concluding remarks and observations are presented in the closing section.

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-10
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content: In this work smoothed particle hydrodynamics (SPH) is applied [39].In contrast to finite volume or finite element methods it implicitly tracks the interface without requiring computationally demanding interface location and tracking algorithms making it particularly suitable for simulations that involve complex interfaces movements.SPH particles convect with the flow field eliminating the need for complex re-meshing or moving meshes.The method also is highly adaptable for simulating complex powder bed structures and fluid-solid boundaries, as different particles can be used for different materials.Additionally, the SPH method is stable for strong interface deformations,which makes it an ideal choice for simulating dynamic melt-pools and the balling process.For the accurate prediction of melt pool morphology and balling a WCsPH multi-phase model [4O] is employed,extended by transport-velocity [41] and consistent boundary conditions [42]. For an accurate representation of melt pool dynamics,pressure,viscous, and gravity forces are taken into account. Evaporation effects on the melt are considered by a recoil-pressure model [43].To account for the driving forces of balling,both capillary and Marangoni forces as well as wetting conditions are incorporated at the melt surface following [44]. A wetting angle of 7O degrees is chosen based on experimental contact angles measurements [8,45] and the cross section morphology in [38]. A precise representation of the energy balance is achieved by modeling thermal conduction in melt,powder and substrate [46],convective cooling byan ambient gas,evaporative cooling,a laser heat source,and solid-liquid phase change,considering the latent heat of melting and solidification.Material models from literature are applied to account for the temperature dependence of viscosity,surface tension,thermal conductivity,heat capacity and laser absorptivity,see A.3.

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-11
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content:
No ambient gas flow is induced and the surrounding gas is treated as isothermal to represent convective cooling.Thermal expansion within the melt pool and possibly resulting buoyancy forces are ignored. Thermal radiation and viscous heating are discarded.The applied absorptivity model accounts for the incidence angle,the dependence on temperature and an energy input at the material surface.As it does not consider multi-reflections within the vapor cavity,absorptivity is increased to match the target melt pool dimensions.While recoil pressure and evaporative cooling are included, mass loss due to evaporation is neglected.To account for increased viscosity of the melt in the mushy zone and to stabilize the simulations the dynamic viscosity is increased by a factor of ten, following [47,48]. The powder layer is explicitly resolved, yet powder particle motion is not incorporated at this stage.

The conservation laws of mass,momentum and energy govern the fluid mechanics and energy balance of balling.For incompressible fluids, the set of equations in Lagrangian form is

$$
\begin{array} { r l } & { \frac { d \rho } { d t } = - \rho \mathrm { { \nabla } } \cdot \mathbf { v } , } \\ & { \frac { d \mathbf { v } } { d t } = \mathbf { F } ^ { p } + \mathbf { F } ^ { \nu } + \mathbf { F } ^ { \sigma } + \mathbf { F } ^ { e v } + \mathbf { F } ^ { g } , } \\ & { \frac { d h } { d t } = Q ^ { \lambda } + Q ^ { e v } + Q ^ { l } , } \end{array}
$$

where $\rho , \textbf { v }$ and $h$ are density,velocity，and enthalpy,respectively. Lagrangian-particle acceleration is due to pressure $( \mathbf { F } ^ { p } )$ ，viscous $( \mathbf { F } ^ { \nu } )$ surface tension $( \mathbf { F } ^ { \sigma } )$ ，recoil pressure $( \mathbf { F } ^ { e v } )$ and gravity $( \mathbf { F } ^ { g } )$ forces. Changes in enthalpy are induced by thermal conduction $\left( Q ^ { \lambda } \right)$ ，evaporative cooling $( Q ^ { e v } )$ and laser irradiation $\left( Q ^ { l } \right)$ ：

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-12
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content:
Pressure forces follow from gradients of the pressure field $p$ as

$$
\mathbf { F } ^ { p } = - \frac { 1 } { \rho } \nabla p .
$$

Viscous forces are determined by the divergence of the strain rate tensor as

$$
\mathbf { F } ^ { \nu } = \frac { 1 } { \rho } \nabla \cdot \left( \mu \nabla v \right) ,
$$

where $\mu$ is the temperature dependent dynamic viscosity.At the melt ambient-gas interface, both capillary and Marangoni forces,

$$
\mathbf { F } ^ { \sigma } = \frac { 1 } { \rho } \left[ \sigma \kappa \mathbf { n } + \nabla _ { s } \sigma \right] ,
$$

are applied.Here, $\sigma , \kappa , \mathbf { n } ,$ and $\nabla _ { s }$ are the surface tension coefficient, interface curvature,interface normal vector and surface tangential gradient operator,respectively.Note that,no special interface capturing and tracking algorithms are needed as SPH naturally handles diferent phases with separate particles.Wetting of melt on the substrate and powder is modeled by Young's equation

$$
\begin{array} { r } { \sigma ^ { s o l i d - g a s } = \sigma ^ { s o l i d - l i q u i d } + \sigma ^ { l i q u i d - g a s } \cos { \theta } , } \end{array}
$$

where an equilibrium between solid, liquid and gas surface tension is achieved at the weting angle $\theta$ .To account for the recoil pressure force we apply an approach based on the Clausius-Clapeyron equation for ideal gases assuming a constant latent heat of phase change

$$
\mathbf { F } ^ { e v } = \frac { 1 } { \rho } A ~ c _ { 1 } ~ p _ { \infty } \exp \left( \frac { A H _ { m o l } } { R } \left( \frac { 1 } { T } - \frac { 1 } { T _ { e v } } \right) \right) ,
$$

with the evaporating surface area A,coefficient $c _ { 1 } ~ = ~ 0 . 5 4$ ，ambient pressure $p _ { \infty }$ ,molar latent heat of evaporation $\Delta H _ { m o l }$ ,universal gas constant $R _ { i }$ ，temperature $T$ and boiling temperature $T _ { e v }$ ,respectively [49]. Finally, gravity $g$ acts as body force

$$
\mathbf { F } ^ { g } = - g .
$$

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-13
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content:
On the right-hand-side of the energy equation,Fourier's law of thermal conduction

$$
Q ^ { \lambda } = \nabla \cdot \left( \lambda \nabla T \right) ,
$$

with thermal conductivity $\lambda$ is used in the melt, gas,and solid phase. Evaporative cooling of the melt is determined from the enthalpy flux of the evaporating material. Here, the mass flux approximation from [49] is given by

$$
J _ { e v } = c _ { 2 } c _ { 3 } p _ { r } \sqrt { \frac { M } { 2 \pi R T } } ,
$$

where the coefficient $c _ { 2 } = 0 . 8 2$ and the sticking coefficient $c _ { 3 } = 1$ are chosen according to [49]. In Eq. (11), $p _ { r }$ is the recoil pressure and $M$ the atomic mass of the evaporating (melt-） material. Evaporative cooling follows as

$$
Q ^ { e v } = - A \left( h + h _ { e v } \right) J _ { e v } ,
$$

where both the enthalpy $h$ and the specific heat of evaporation $h _ { e v }$ are considered.This heat sink is applied at the interface between melt and the ambient gas phase.Finally, laser irradiation is modeled by a Gaussian energy source term

$$
Q ^ { l } = - \alpha \varOmega A \ \frac { 8 \ P } { \pi d _ { s } ^ { 2 } } \exp \left( - 8 \left( \frac { r _ { 0 } - r } { d _ { s } } \right) ^ { 2 } \right)
$$

with absorptivity $\alpha$ ,directional absorptance correction $\varOmega$ ,laser power $P$ ,laser spot diameter $d _ { s }$ ,laser axis location $r _ { 0 }$ and radial coordinate $r$ $\varOmega$ is approximated by Schlick's approach $\varOmega = 1 - ( 1 - \cos ( \phi ) ) ^ { 5 }$ ，where $\phi$ is the angle between the laser axis and the incident area normal vector [5O]. The energy deposition is considered to occur at the phase interface only [43].

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-14
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content:
Phase change is modeled in SPH by simply transforming particles from one phase to another.As criterion,we use an enthalpy threshold where latent heat of fusion and solidification is considered within the threshold.The rate of temperature change in the mushy zone between the two states is considered through specific heat capacity models, see A.3. The set of equations is closed by Cole's [51] equation of state $$ p = p _ { 0 } \left( \left( \frac { \rho } { \rho _ { 0 } } \right) ^ { \gamma } - 1 \right) . $$ ![](images/ce7f82252b1e0b155ef622892cdb34df058535a3f28a2542a5f270b8da9319ae.jpg) Fig.1.Domain dimensions of substrate,powder and ambient gas. Laser scan path from $x = 0$ to $x = 3 0 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ Table 1 Single melt track simulation parameters.
Serial numberLaser power [W]Scan speed [mm/s]LED [J/m]VED [J/mm³]Balling

Here,reference pressure $p _ { 0 }$ and isotropic exponent $\gamma$ are chosen to limit density variations to $1 \%$ of the reference density $\rho _ { 0 }$ The set of equations is evolved in time using an explicit VelocityVerlet time integration scheme [52]. The maximum allowed time-step size follows from the most restrictive stability condition out of the viscous,surface tension,recoil pressure,thermal conduction,and CFL criterion [44,46,53,54].

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-15
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content:
We study single melt track balling of Inconel 718 material at different process conditions.The numerical results are validated with experimental data of Scime and Beuth [38].In their work,ex-situ recordings of single melt tracks are presented for 36 parameter sets.At each power and scan speed combination1O single tracks are generated with an EOS M290 machine.The investigated process map covers both stable parameters for constant melt tracks,as well as unstable parameter sets showing defects like balling.

Scime and Beuth use the nickel alloy Inconel 718.The base plate is an Inconel 718 plate from McMaster-Carr (P/N:1099N8) and the powder material is Inconel 718 from EOS with a composition of Ni $5 0 { - } 5 5 \ \mathrm { w t \% }$ ,Cr17.0-21.0 wt%,Nb $4 . 7 5 { - } 5 . 5 \ \mathrm { w t \% }$ ，Mo $2 . 8 \substack { - 3 . 3 \mathrm { \ w t \% } }$ T $\ddot { 1 } 0 . 6 5  – 1 . 1 5 \mathrm { w t } \%$ ，For an accurate representation of the material, temperature dependent material properties are incorporated into the numerical model. The corresponding material models are extracted from [43] and listed in A.3.

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-16
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content: In Scime and Beuth [38] a powder layer thickness of $7 0 \pm 2 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ is chosen to achieve a target nominal $4 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ fused layer build-up. Thus,a consolidation factor $\left( 1 - \rho _ { p o w d e r } / \rho _ { f u s e d } \right)$ of $4 0 \%$ is assumed. No further specifications about the powder size distribution are made.To mimic a comparable powder bed setup,we apply the drop and roll algorithm from Zhou et al.[55].The initial powder-size distribution of particles to be dropped follows a normal distribution defined bya mean diameter of $3 0 \mu \mathrm { m } ,$ ,a standard deviation of $1 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,and a minimum and maximum particle diameter of $2 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ and $5 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } .$ ,respectively. Particles extending beyonda layer height of $7 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ are discarded.The resulting powder bed is defined by a packing density of $5 5 \%$ ,slightly below the assumed $6 0 \%$ of the experiments.

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-17
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content: The same computational setup is used in all simulations.The dimensions of the physical domain are set to $3 2 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } \ { } x \ 3 0 0 \ { \mu \mathrm { m } } \ x \ 3 7 0 \ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ (length,width,height).It is enclosed by three layers of boundary particles.With a uniform spatial discretization of $\Delta x = 3 . 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ ,the total number of SPH particles amounts to 9395040.The laser spot is resolved byabout 33 SPH particles across its diameter,and the smallest powder particle is resolved by at least 5 SPH particles across its diameter. In Fig.1 the simulation setup is shown.At initialization, the domain consists of a $3 2 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } \times 3 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } \times 2 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ substrate plate,covered by a powder layer of thickness $l _ { p } = 7 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ .The remainder of the domain is filled with argon,shown in light blue in Fig.1.In correspondence with the experiments,the domain is initialized at $8 0 ^ { \circ } C$ to resemble preheating.At all domain boundaries,isothermal no-slip boundary conditions are enforced.The laser is initially placed at position $[ 0 , 0 , 0 ]$ as indicated in Fig.1.Throughout the simulation the laser moves at a constant scan speed $u$ .The simulation is stopped once the laser has travelled $3 0 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .The laser spot diameter is set in accordance with the experiments to $1 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ 、All investigated process parameter sets of laser power and laser scan speed are listed together with their corresponding linear energy densities $L E D \ = \ P / u$ and volumetric energy densities $V E D = { \cal P } / \left( u d _ { s } l _ { p } \right)$ in Table 1. The quintic spline kernel is applied with a smoothing length equal to the particle spacing and cut-off radius $r = 3 \varDelta x$ .

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-18
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content:
Forareference length of $2 1 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ ,reference velocity of $1 0 ~ \mathrm { m / s }$ and a numerical sound speed of $1 0 0 ~ \mathrm { m / s }$ the physical time step size is 7.95 ns.

To allow for high numerical resolutions at moderate computation times,the algorithm utilizes the scaleable OpenFPM $\mathsf { C } \mathsf { + + }$ framework [56]. The applied domain decomposition,communication,data structures,memory management and cell lists ensure an execution of the comprehensive set of numerical models at reasonable computation times.All simulations were carried out on NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2080 Ti GPUs,and the computational time for $2 5 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { s } }$ physical time ranged from 291 to $3 6 0 \ \mathrm { h }$ depending on the process parameter set.

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-19
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content:
Since melt pool dimensions are of particular importance for the melt breakup process,we first validate them by comparison with experimental data.Next, the ability of the model to predict balling and non-balling parameter sets is assessed.Finally,the melt pool breakup and balling process is investigated to clarify detailed defect mechanisms.

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-20
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content: In order to validate the numerical model,we first compare the accuracy of the simulated single melt tracks to experimental data. The process map from Scime and Beuth [38] suggests a smooth melt pool without balling at the process conditions for cases $\# 1$ ，#2，#4, $\# 5$ and $\# 7$ in Table 1.Top view,solidified track cross section,and longitudinal melt-pool profile of case $\# 1$ are shown as example of a stable single melt track in Fig.2.At these process conditions a continuous melt pool without significant variance in width develops and is maintained along the scan path. The color coded temperature field,Fig.2,indicates high temperature within the radiation zone followed by a rapid cooling towards the trailing region of the meltpool.The longitudinal cross-section view reveals a vapor cavity at the laser irradiation zone followed by a smooth melt-pool topology. The powder layer is fully melted and a suficient penetration depth into the substrate ensures fusion between the consecutive layers.In the vertical cross-section view the maximum track width $l _ { w } .$ ，penetration depth into the substrate $l _ { p }$ and consolidated material layer build-up $l _ { m }$ are sketched.The respective total track height follows from the sum of build-up and penetration depth as $\boldsymbol { l } _ { h } = \boldsymbol { l } _ { p } + \boldsymbol { l } _ { m }$ . Layer build-up is achieved as the new substrate height $l _ { 1 }$ exceeds the initial substrate height $l _ { 0 }$ as shown in Fig. 2 (c).

In Table 2,single-melt-track width and depth results are summarized.For cases #1,#2, $\# 4$ $\# 5$ and $\# 7$ the total track height is stated while for the balling cases $\# 3$ and $\# 6$ the penetration depth is given. We compare the results with lines of constant melt pool geometry from Scime and Beuth [38].With a melt track width of $1 4 8 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ for case $\# 4$ $1 5 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ forcase $\# 7$ ,and track depths of $1 1 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $1 1 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ for cases $\# 1$ and $\# 2$ ,the experimental data are met within an relative deviation of $1 5 ~ \%$ .Single-track widths and depths of all simulations reside between their corresponding lines of constant melt pool dimension,see Fig.5 in [38].Hence, the results indicate the ability of the numerical model to accurately predict the single melt track proportions. name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-22
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content: on these findings,no balling is expected for cases $\# 2$ and $\# 5$ ，while balling is likely to occur in cases $\# 3$ and $\# 6$ 、Hence，we choose these four parameter sets to assess the numerical prediction of melt pool breakup and balling.Fig.3 presents the simulation results in the longitudinal cut through the domain center. Case $\# 3$ is shown at the time step where the laser is turned off while cases $\# 2$ $\# 5$ and $\# 6$ are shown at the last time steps before the melt pool separation.In all four cases we find melt aggregation and a disturbed track topology in the region of initial melt pool development.At the onset of a single melt track the pool is more likely to accumulate,as shown in [1,25],even when there is no powder bed present [36].We believe this enhanced accumulation facilitates baling. Therefore,we disregard initial humps and focus the validation on the subsequent melt track.The topologies of cases $\# 2$ and $\# 5$ remain homogeneous for the most part and only a marginal amount of melt separates in case $\# 2$ ,see Fig.3 (a) and (b).In contrast,large melt agglomerates separate from the main pool in cases $\# 3$ and $\# 6$ ,see Fig.3 (c) and (d).The developing balls extend over the powder layer height.Thus,the increased likelihood of balling for cases $\# 3$ and $\# 6$ as found in the experiments is confirmed by the simulations. Besides the indication of balling and non-balling conditions,the results reveal an increased tendency of melt separation,inhomogeneous track topology and disturbed melt pool at higher laser scan speeds and a lower laser power.

fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content: Next,the occurrence of balling at different process parameter settings is compared with experimental data.In [38],the probabilities of balling at various points in the power-scan-speed map are presented. They are identified from the number of examined cross-sections that exhibit a balling morphology at the specific process parameters.Based

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-24
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content:
The simulations allow for a precise determination of melt pool ratios and to quantify forces relevant for the cause and development of balling.In Fig.4 and Fig.5 the melt pool evolution for cases $\# 3$ and $\# 6$ are shown in top view and as centered cut section,respectively.We distinguish four regions of the melt pool: (I) depression, (II) transition,(II) neck,and (IV) tail end. In direct proximity of the laser beam strong recoil pressure and Marangoni forces induce a depression of the melt pool. Further downstream the transition region follows,characterized by decay of the high temperature gradients,the absence of prominent melt extrusion and a constant melt pool width. The section with contracting melt pool post laser-exposure is called the neck-region.The following tail end region eventually forms the isolated ball. Both the depression and transition region appear quasisteady while the neck and tail region vary periodically to form the emerging balls.The depression constitutes the deepest penetration into the substrate.It is followed by a gradual decrease of melt pool depth in the transition region. The contraction of melt at the tail end leads to a hemispherical shape which exceeds the powder layer height. In contrast, layer build-up in the neck region is marginal.As a result, the solidified track topology consists of a ball followed by a cavity. Note,while the melt pool size of case $\# 6$ exceeds the one of case $\# 3$ the ball size is smaller in case $\# 6$ .The ball size depends on the onset of necking. In case $\# 3$ necking starts further upstream, leading to a larger tail region and eventually a larger ball. Consequently,the cavity following the ball is more pronounced in case $\# 3$ as well.

![](images/d79d80a75775b5114774da7ef292472832b9c985469371e5910349fb9852f4b4.jpg)

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-26
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content: Melt pool breakup shown in Fig.4and Fig.5 exhibits characteristics of Plateau-Rayleigh instability.A common parameter to evaluate this instability in melt pools is the length to width ratio [7,21].The length to width threshold ratios found in literature range between 2 and $\pi$ [13].A clear indication as to which analytical model is most precise still is missing and their overall applicability is questioned [31].On the one hand,for process conditions of low melt penetration numerical studies from literature show melt breakup prior to the predicted ratios [lO].On the other hand, the stabilizing effect of melt penetration into the substrate is discarded completely in the analytical models suggesting an underestimation of the breakup ratios [7]. The resulting length to width ratios for cases $\# 3$ and $\# 6$ are 11.3 and 11.4,respectively.While these ratios agree with the available models they cannot confirm their accuracy as they are well beyond the model thresholds. Large length to width ratios for cases $\# 2$ and $\# 5$ indicate stable melt tracks beyond the analytical model predictions.This discrepancy most likely originates from the stabilization due to a considerate melt penetration which is discarded in the analytical models.Nonetheless, the present simulation results confirm the trend of long,shallow and narrow melt pools to be less stable.

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-27
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content: Now,we take a closer look at the influence of Marangoni and capillary forces on the necking and breakup behavior.In this work,a linear surface-tension dependence on temperature is incorporated,see $\sigma$ in A.3.Its impact on the melt pool is twofold.First, the capillary forces normal to the interfaces reduce with temperature.And more importantly, tangential Marangoni forces occur as a result of non-zero surface tension gradients along the interface.In Fig.6 (b) and (c),case $\# 3$ is shown shortly after the onset of necking at time $1 9 6 0 \ \mu \mathrm { s } ,$ as well as shortly before the pinch-off at time $2 1 6 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { s }$ .The melt pool is color coded with the temperature. The lines $\textcircled{1} . \textcircled{4}$ and $\textcircled{1 }$ correspond to the transverse surface tension plots in Fig.6 (a). In Fig. 6 (d) the surface tension along lines $\textcircled{4}$ and $\textcircled{8}$ is shown. The highest heat content and surface-tension gradients are found in the depression region.Downstream,high temperatures at the melt pool center lead to a low surface-tension that rapidly increases towards the cooler melt pool edges.In the transition region the surface tension at the melt pool sides remains constant while it increases along the center.As the Marangoni force results from the surface-tension gradient, their intensity can be estimated from the slope of the surface tension plots.It is concluded that a strong Marangoni force only is present in the depression region and quickly decreases in the transition region.Since surface-tension gradients decay over time,the Marangoni force attenuates as well. Shortly before ball pinch-off,only a weak Marangoni force acts in the neck region. Consequently,the Marangoni force,which promotes melt spreading, decays as necking progresses.

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-28
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content:
To investigate the impact of capillary forces,we study the evolution of pressure in the neck region over time. Fig.7 (a) shows the pressure contour of case $\# 3$ at times 1960,2080 and $2 1 4 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { s }$ in a cut through the melt pool center. Color coding corresponds to the normalized pressure field.The white $\mathbf { X }$ -marked line through the neck region indicates the path of the pressure plot in Fig.7 (b).As the neck contracts, pressure increases.This is a direct response to a stronger capillary force.As a result,strong pressure gradients arise towards the transition and tail end region.These pressure gradients in turn induce a convective flux outward of the neck region.To quantify the impact of melt convection on the neck contraction and balling,the average specific momentum $\begin{array} { r } { I _ { s p } = \sum ( m _ { i } v _ { i } ) / \sum ( m _ { i } ) } \end{array}$ is plotted over time in Fig.7 (c),with particle mass $m _ { i }$ and particle velocity $v _ { i }$ ： $I _ { s p }$ is evaluated in the downstream and upstream neck regions $x = 1 7 5 0 - 1 9 8 0 { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ and $x = 1 9 8 0 - 2 1 8 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ respectively.Shortly before breakup,melt convects towards the neck region.Then,as the pressure in the neck rises,momentum changes direction,and following breakup melt convects outwards from the neck region.Capillary force leads to a pressure increase in the neck that induces melt convection,which induces further necking and ultimately to melt pool breakup.

content:
The melt pool breakup is followed by a melt contraction towards a ball.One common explanation of the balling process is the competing mechanisms of solidification and spreading [8,33,34]. From the assumption of no impact speed of the melted material it is concluded that melt flow is mainly driven by capillary forces and inertia.A comparison of the time scale of super-heat removal to the spreading time is then used to predict the presence or absence of balling. Faster solidification than spreading timescales are claimed to lead to a premature stop of spreading and thus induce balling.In accordance to [33],the solidification time in the present study is approximated by $\tau ^ { s o l } = 2 \left( w ^ { 2 } / 3 \alpha \right) \ln \left( T _ { 0 } - T _ { \infty } \right) / \left( T _ { s } - T _ { \infty } \right)$ For cases $\# 3$ and $\# 6$ follow solidification times of $5 1 ~ \mu \mathrm { s }$ and $4 2 ~ { \mu \mathrm { s } }$ .Here,melt track widths of $w =$ $1 1 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ and $w = 1 2 7 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } ;$ ，thermal diffusivities of $\alpha = 6 . 7 8 e ^ { - 6 } ~ \mathrm { { m } } ^ { 2 } / \mathrm { { s } }$ and $\alpha = 7 . 4 3 e ^ { - 6 } \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 } / \mathrm { s }$ ，super heat temperatures $T _ { 0 } = 1 5 7 9 \mathrm { K }$ and $T _ { 0 } = 1 5 6 3 \mathrm { K } ,$ an ambient temperature of ${ { T } _ { \infty } } \mathrm { ~ = ~ } 3 5 3 \mathrm { ~ K ~ }$ and solidus temperature of
