name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-32
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content:
$T _ { s } = 1 5 2 8 \mathrm { ~ K ~ }$ are applied,espectivelyrom $\tau ^ { s p r e a d } = \left( \rho w ^ { 3 } / \sigma \right) ^ { 0 . 5 }$ the spreading timescales $7 4 ~ { \mu \mathrm { s } }$ and $9 2 ~ \mu \mathrm { s }$ follow for cases $\# 3$ and $\# 6$ Here, density $\rho = 7 7 3 3 ~ \mathrm { k g } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 3 }$ and surface tension coeficients $\sigma = 1 . 8 9 ~ \mathrm { N / m }$ are used in both cases.The applied material variables are the average values determined in the ball at pinch-off.At that time,most of the melt super-heat is already removed and the tail end spreading is already stopped.As the evaluated spreading time exceeds the solidification time,no melt spreading is expected in both cases.

Overall, the simulation results support the theoretical model. It is interesting to note,that in contrast to the model assumption of zero impact speed, the melt has considerable non-zero momentum after pinch-off,see Fig.7(c).In Figs.8 and 9 the tail end region of cases $\# 3$ and $\# 6$ and their respective solidification fronts are shown shortly after the melt pool breakup.The melt pool is color coded by temperature.In both cases we find a contracting melt pool rather than a flow dominated by spreading forces.In case $\# 3$ the melt contracts from time $t = 2 1 8 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { s }$ to time $t = 2 2 0 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { s }$ at which point the solidification front is caught up.The same behavior is found in case $\# 6$ where melt contraction and solidification define the balling process.We conclude that, when balling occurs following a necking process,the assumption of zero impact speed of the model by [33] no longer is valid. Instead,the balling process is best characterized by an advancing solidification front at the rear of the tail region and melt contraction followed by an advancing solidification at the front of the tail region.

fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content:
Single melt track simulations are conducted at seven scan-speedlaser-power settings to investigate balling behavior of Inconel 718 material.The present smoothed particle hydrodynamics model accurately predicts multi-phase dynamics including strong interface deformations.The numerical model considers all relevant thermal- and fluid-mechanics effects,including evaporation-induced recoil pressure and cooling as well as capillary，Marangoni and wetting interface forces.

The validity of the model to investigate the balling phenomenon is established by comparison with experimental data.As the breakup is very sensitive to the apparent melt pool dimensions,we compare width and depth with [38] and find good agreement. In addition,the model capability to predict parameter sets for balling and non-balling melt tracks is validated for two power settings.We identify clearly absence and presence of balls as well as rough and smooth melt pool topologies at the respective conditions.

An investigation of the surface-tension distribution in transversal and longitudinal scan direction reveals the connection of Marangoni forces to the melt pool dynamics.Particular important to the balling process is the decay of surface tension gradients in the necking region during the melt contraction.It indicates a related decay of stabilizing melt flow towards the pool edges.

name: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71-part-34
fileName: 2023 - AM - Zöller, Adams, Adami - Numerical investigation of balling defects in laser-based powder bed fusion of metals with Inconel 71.md
content:
In contrast,capillary forces within the neck increase as necking progresses both due to an increase of curvature and a reduction in temperature.A resulting high capillary pressure induces a convective melt flux away from the neck region,ultimately leading to the pinchoff of the tail region.As a result,material build-up within the neck area is marginal.Analytical estimates for breakup conditions cannot be confirmed by the numerical results as the melt pool shows to be stable well beyond the model thresholds.This deviation can be explained by stabilizing melt pool penetration into the substrate,which is disregarded by the analytical estimates.We find a comparable breakup behavior for both investigated power settings.The ball size shows to depend more on the necking onset rather than the size of the melt pool itself.

The balling process is best characterized by an advancing solidification front at the rear,and an initial melt contraction at the front that is followed by an advancing melt front at a later stage.Thus,from the simulations the common explanation of the competing mechanisms of spreading and solidification cannot be confirmed.Instead,we find that capillary forces in the neck region induce a melt contraction which is stronger than melt spreading.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r-part-1
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r.md
content:
# Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser remelting in directed energy deposition
Myong Joon Kim\*, Christopher Saldana

eorgeWdltoei

# ARTICLEINFO
Keywords:   
Powder directed energy deposition   
Thin wall deposition   
Laser re-melting   
Defect removal   
XCT porosity analysis

# ABSTRACT
Blown-powder directed energy deposition (DED) is especially useful for depositing on an existing part for the purpose ofrepair or adding features.Thin substrate deposition,wherein the width ofthe substrate is smaller than the laser diameter,is an important configuration for building and repairing complex components in various geometries.The present study seeks to understand the eficacy of in-line post-processng methods based on laser remelting (LR) forreducing internal (e.g.,porosity)and external (e.g.,surface roughness) for such thin-walled repair configurations.In this work,different levels of LR energy densityand substrate width were evaluated using the LR process.Post processing outcomes in terms of deposit geometry as well as spatial distribution of porosity,pore density,pore volume fraction,pore diameter,and surface roughness were evaluated using X-ray microcomputed tomography and optical profilometry.The results showed that LR reduced pore density up to 88 $\%$ and reduced areal surface roughness to $4 . 1 5 9 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .At some threshold,increasing LR energy density increased surface waviness and modified deposition geometry,this indicative of limits to the post processng method. Strategies for using LR to reduce total porosity,near-surface porosity,and improving surface roughness are briefly discussed.
summary: ABSTRACT, ARTICLEINFO, Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser remelting in directed energy deposition

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r-part-2
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r.md
content: Blown-powder directed energy deposition (DED) is a promising additive manufacturing technique for both near-net-shape manufacturing and repair.In DED,material is delivered through an inert gas stream in powder form into the molten pool of the substrate that is created by a laser-based heat source.To successfully build a desired part,process parameters must be thoughtfully chosen to the purpose of the application.Laser parameters (e.g.,spot size, power, scan speed), powder parameters (e.g.,size distribution,mass flowrate,production method), substrate parameters (e.g.,geometry,material),and carrier/shielding gas parameters (e.g., flowrate,gas type) act to determine deposition quality (e.g.,distribution and morphology of defects,grain structure/ size,geometry,surface roughness).These parameters govern the dimensions,quality,consistency of the melt pool,the rate of powder catchment,solidification rate,and thermal history.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r-part-3
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r.md
content: However,several potential defects still inherently exist that cannot be mitigated by changing processing parameters.External and internal defects such as surface roughness and porosity could be detrimental to fatigue life [1] and hardness [2] of the as-built samples.Studies have shown to successfully mitigate the external defects on bulk structures via mechanical finishing processes (machining [3],burnishing [4],shot peening [5],and ultrasonic cavitation abrasive finishing [6]),chemical finishing process [7],and electrochemical finishing process [8].Mechanical processes,however,are challenging to implement for thin wall geometries due to deflection,and chemical/electrochemical processes are not suitable for repair manufacturing application where the parent material could not undergo such process.Internal defects in bulk materials are decreased through hot isostatic pressing (HIP)[9,lO] and shot peening [11],and these methods have shown to improve component density through pore closure.AHIP treatment,however,is limited in that it only effectively closes internal pores and is also a separate process not integrable within AM equipment. Shot peening may offer some opportunity for surface pore closure but would be relatively challenging to implement in between layers to mitigate internal pores.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r-part-4
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r.md
content:
In contrast to these approaches,laser polishing or laser remelting (LR) can address these drawbacks.LR has been shown to improve external [12-16] and internal AMdefects [17-2O] by melting the peaks and filling the valleys of the surface,and by closing pores and holes. Prior works have investigated the impact of LR on porosity and mechanical properties through experiments and simulations.Xin et al. [17] investigated the effect of LR scan speed on microstructural evolutions and Laves phase which affects material hardness. The LR process refined Laves phase and porosity improving average hardness slightly in IN718.Wei et al.[18] showed significant decrease in residual stress, formation of strong textures,increased elongation,and no improvements in tensile strength by LR.Chen et al.[19] explored the effect of LR on redistribution of Si element on the surface improving hardness,and wear resistance.Yasa et al.[2O] showed improvement in part density, surface roughness,and microstructure of selective laser melting (SLM) parts.Zhao and Cong [21,22] showed improved fatigue crack propagation and thermal fatigue resistance after LR processing. These works have demonstrated the effect of LR processing on microstructural evolution,part density,and various mechanical properties.Recent studies have shown capability to effectively decrease internal and external defects by LR processing,however most of these studies have focused on larger-scale bulk depositions.In contrast, there remains limited understanding regarding defect mitigation by LR processing in thin-walled depositions where substrate-related geometry may influence process effectiveness.This is especially applicable for aerospace components such as compressors and turbine blades where thin-walled geometric features are prevalent.

Table 1 Experimental parameter sets.

In this study,single-track, single-layer deposits were investigated to explore the effect of substrate width and processing parameters on LR process outcomes.Different substrate widths were used to simulate geometric variations in the parent substrate geometry. Different $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ levels were applied to as-deposited samples to understand the impact of this parameter on process outcomes.Geometry，porosity，surface roughness,and microstructure were systematically characterized across the parameter range investigated.Across the parameter space investigated,substrate width and $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ had marked effects on the process outcomes.A phenomenological basis for these observations is provided based on changes in cooling rate and melt pool flow mechanisms and these are described in the ensuing discussion.

content:
Gas atomized Inconel $^ ©$ 625 (IN625) powder,a widely used nickelbased super alloy,manufactured from Praxair was used for the DED experiments.Particle size analysis showed that $9 6 . 4 ~ \%$ of the particles had diameter between $4 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ and $7 4 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ and $2 . 4 ~ \%$ and $1 . 2 ~ \%$ of the particles had diameter below $4 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ and above $7 4 \ \mu \mathrm { m } .$ ,respectively.A Mazak VC-5oo AM was used to create single-track deposits on IN625 substrates.An Oerlikon powder hopper delivered powder through a 4.0 mm outer diameter and $2 . 5 \ \mathrm { m m }$ inner diameter tube with argon gas feeding the powder coaxially to the laser with a maximum mass flowrate of $6 . 1 5 5 { \mathrm { g / m i n } }$ .The additive tool (Hybrid Manufacturing Technologies) had a1 kW 1O7O nm continuous wave YLR fiber laser (IPG Photonics). The laser had an output stability of $\pm 2 . 0 \%$ with smallest laser spot size of $3 2 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .The focal distance of the additive head,which is the distance from the tip of the nozzle to the substrate,was adjusted to ensure a $d =$ $1 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m }$ diameter spot size on the substrate surface.

Table 1 summarizes the parameters used in both the deposition and LR experiments.Substrate width and laser scanning speed were varied, and other conditions are kept constant,as shown in Table 1. The overall quality of DED deposits is governed by the applied laser energy density during deposition and is given by Eq. (1) [23]:

$$
E _ { d } = \frac { P } { V d }
$$

content:
where, $\mathrm { E _ { d } }$ is the energy density at a given unit area $\scriptstyle ( { \mathrm { J / m m } } ^ { 2 } )$ ,Pisthe laser power (W),V is the scan speed $\mathrm { ( m m / s ) }$ ,and d is the laser spot size (mm).In the present experiments,spot size was constant at $\mathbf { d } = 1 . 0 \mathrm { m m }$ Preliminary experiments were carried out to determine appropriate range of laser power,powder mass flowrate,laser scan speed and remelting scan speed.Laser power was explored from $P = 1 0 0 ~ \mathrm { W }$ to $P =$ 300 W in increments of $\Delta P = 2 5$ W with scan speeds of $\mathsf { V } = \{ 3 . 3 3$ ,6.67, $1 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s \}$ .From these initial experiments,laser power settings of $P =$ $1 7 5 \mathrm { ~ W ~ }$ to $P = 2 2 5$ W and scan speed of $\mathrm { V } = 3 . 3 3 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ resulted in the most continuous and uniform geometry along the bead without melting the substrate lower than its original height [24].Powder mass flowrate was tested at $\mathbf { f } = \{ 1 . 5 , 3 . 0$ $4 . 5 \mathrm { g / m i n } \}$ .Here $P = 1 7 5$ W and powder mass flowrate of $\mathbf { f } = 1 . 5 ~ \mathrm { g / m i n }$ provided the most consistent geometry with least surface discoloration due to oxidation.For the LR process,scan speeds of $\mathsf { V } _ { \mathrm { L R } } = \{ 3 . 3 3 , 6 . 6 7 , 1 0 . 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s \}$ were used and corresponded to $\mathrm { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } } = \{ 1 7 . 5$ ,26.3,and $5 2 . 5 ~ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 2 } } \}$ ,respectively.

In the present experiments,single-track,single-layer beads were deposited on the edge of annealed IN625 sheet metal,as illustrated in

Fig.1.An illustrative image of thin substrate deposition.

The sheet metal has density of $8 . 5 8 ~ \mathrm { g / c m ^ { 3 } }$ ,hardness of Rockwell B95,and thermal conductivity of $9 . 8 \mathrm { ~ W / M ^ { - } C }$ at 23C.The substrates used had widths of $\mathbf { w } = \{ 0 . 5 , 0 . 8$ ,1.0, $2 . 0 \mathrm { m m } \}$ .Deposition conditions in terms of laser power,powder mass flowrate,laser spot diameter,and carrier gas/shield gas/nozzle gas volumetric flowrate were kept constant.For the LR process,laser power and gas conditions were kept constant and different LR scan speeds of $\mathsf { V } _ { \mathrm { L R } } = \{ 0 , 3 . 3 3$ ,6.67 and 10 $\mathrm { m m } / s \}$ were used,corresponding to applied energy density of $\mathbf { E } _ { \mathrm { { L R } } } = \{ 0 ;$ 17.5, 26.3, $5 2 . 5 ~ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 2 } } \}$ ,respectively.The effect of cooling rate and LR process on geometry,surface roughness,porosity,and grain structures were inspected with 16 single-track deposits with parameter sets given in Table 1.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r-part-10
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r.md
content: Deposit geometry and internal porosity were measured by X-ray computed tomography (XCT) using a Zeiss Metrotom 8oo.To ensure scan quality,contrast between solid and air phases was maximized by optimizing the operating voltage and current to $1 3 0 ~ \mathrm { k V }$ and $6 1 \ \mu \mathrm { A } ,$ respectively.An $8 \mu \mathrm { m } .$ /voxel resolution was used.Further,the deposition scan direction was aligned with sample rotation axis so to minimize the X-raypenetration depth.Ring and star artifacts were removed in postprocessing of the data.Beam hardening was reduced by use of a 0.5 mm copper filter at the X-ray source.The scans were reconstructed and analyzed using VolumeGraphics software.Acylinder-type geometry was fitted to each of the deposits,as shown in Fig.2A,B.To determine the radius of the single-track deposits,a cylindrical shape was fitted to the XCT scan of deposit, specifically to densely sampled set of points from the surface of the image as illustrated in Fig.2B.Gaussian least squares fit was used to fit a cylinder to the set of points that minimized the sum over all squared deviations of all fit points relative to the fitted geometry element.The surface of the XCT scans were determined by ISO5O surface determination method between two peaks (a background peak and a foreground peak) in the grey value histogram of a XCT dataset. The determined surface by using the ISO5O method can be used to accurately measure dimension of the object when the data was assumed to be free from artifacts [25].XCT scans were taken to minimize X-ray artifacts such as scattering artifacts,star artifacts,and beam hardening artifacts. Internal porosity was also evaluated using VolumeGraphics,and measurements were made of each pore's location,diameter,volume,and sphericity.Fig.2C shows a deposit made transparent and with internal porosity shaded according to diameter.
summary: 2.2. Inspection methods for quality outcomes - Part 1/3

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r-part-11
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r.md
content: Surface roughness was inspected with a Zygo ZeGage non-contact, 3D optical surface profilometer for quantitative measurement of areal surface texture parameters,this complying with ISO 25178-2:2012.Of those parameters,height parameters (i.e., $s _ { \mathrm { q } } ,$ （204 $S _ { \mathrm { s k } } , S _ { \mathrm { k u } } )$ which only account for statistical distribution of height values,and a hybrid parameter $( S _ { \mathrm { d r } } )$ which relates to the spatial shape of the signal were used.The rootmean-square height of the surface, $s _ { \mathrm { q } } ,$ can be a more distinguishing value compared to $\mathbf { S _ { a } }$ as it gives more weight to higher amplitude peaks and valleys,whereas $S _ { \mathrm { a } }$ can be zeroed.Skewness of the height distribution, $\mathbf { S } _ { \mathrm { s k } } ,$ indicates if the surface has deeper valleys $( S _ { \mathrm { s k } } < 0 )$ orhas higher peaks $( S _ { \mathrm { s k } } > 0 ) _ { . }$ orsymmetry $( S _ { \mathrm { s k } } = 0 )$ ).Kurtosis, $s _ { \mathrm { k u } } ,$ qualifies the flatness of the height distribution.When $ { S _ { \mathrm { k u } } } = 3 . 0$ ,peaks are shaped as a normal distribution,and $S _ { \mathrm { k u } } > 3 . 0$ is flatter, $S _ { \mathrm { k u } } < 3 . 0$ is sharper than normal distribution shape.To calculate standard deviation of samples across different processing parameters regarding radius,porosity,and surface roughness,3O samples without laser remelting process and 30 samples with laser remelting process $( \mathrm { E _ { L R } } { = } 1 7 . 5 \ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 2 } } )$ at $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 5 \mathrm { m m }$ were manufactured.The standard deviations calculated from the 60 samples were used to represent the deposits that were characterized in this study assuming homoscedasticity.
summary: 2.2. Inspection methods for quality outcomes - Part 2/3

content:
# 3.1.Geometric characterization
The geometry of each of the deposits before and after LR post processing was characterized in terms of the bead radius and this data is summarized in Figs.3 and 4. The initial as-deposited bead geometry exhibited sensitivity to the width of the substrate,where wider substrates resulted in smaller radius deposits.The radius of the as-deposited bead for a substrate width of $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 5 \mathrm { m m }$ was $\{ 1 0 , 1 6$ $4 6 \% \}$ larger than that of samples with substrate widths of $\bf { w } = \{ 0 . 8$ ，1.0, $2 . 0 \mathrm { \ m m } \}$ ， respectively. The LR process generally increased the bead radius.For w $= 0 . 5 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ ,the highest $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ resulted in a $9 . 6 ~ \%$ increase in the deposit radius,whereas for $\mathbf { w } = \{ 0 . 8 , 1 . 0 , 2 . 0 \mathrm { m m } \}$ the deposit size increased by {5.8,4.1, $3 . 1 \ \% \}$ with the same $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ .Thus,as substrate width increased, more energy was absorbed by the substrate,thereby having less effect on the deposit.In a narrower substrate,melt pool is usually wider as it can be seen in Fig.4. The highest $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ used for $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 5 \ : \mathrm { m m }$ also resulted in flattening of the circular deposit geometry cross section (Fig.4D) when compared to the $\mathbf { w } = 2 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m }$ deposit (Fig. 4).

# 3.2.Porosity characterization

content: Fig.5A shows a sample tomographic scan with porosity identified within the deposit.The coordinates of each pore were used to calculate the distribution of pores in the upper and lower half of the bead as illustrated in Fig.5B, C.Fig.6 shows the total pore number density $\left( \mathrm { N } _ { \mathrm { v } } \right)$ at different substrate widths in the as-deposited condition,where $\mathrm { N _ { v } }$ is defined as the total number of pores formed in a single-track deposit divided by the total deposit volume.For a substrate width of $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 5$ mm, the as-deposited total pore number density was $\mathrm { N _ { v } } = 6 6 . 6$ pores/ $\mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ .As substrate width increased to $\mathbf { w } = \{ 0 . 8 , 1 . 0 , 2 . 0 \ : \mathrm { m m } \}$ ,the total pore number density decreased to $\mathbf { N } _ { \mathrm { v } } = \{ 4 8 . 2 , 4 0 . 1 , 3 0 . 1 \ \mathrm { p o r e s / m m } ^ { 3 } \}$ For each of these conditions,the majority of pores ${ \sim } 6 5 \substack { - 7 5 } \ \%$ were located in the upper half of the deposit.The application of the LR process reduced the presence of porosity within the deposits.Fig.6 also shows the effect of increasing $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ on both $\mathrm { N _ { v } }$ for different substrate widths. Increasing $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ decreased $\mathrm { N _ { v } , }$ as $\mathtt { E } _ { \mathrm { { L R } } } = \{ 0$ ，17.5,26.3, $5 2 . 5 ~ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 2 } } \}$ resulted in $\mathrm { N _ { v } } = \{ 6 6 . 6 , 4 1 . 4 , 1 7 . 9 , 7 . 7 \mathrm { p o r e s / m m ^ { 3 } } \}$ at $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 5 \mathrm { m m }$ . This same trend was generally seen for the wider substrate widths,however the changes in porosity as a function of $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ were less significant in those cases.

content: The localized effect of the LR process in the upper regions of the deposit is evident in the evolution of the pore density for the upper and lower regions of the beads,detailed in Fig.7.In this case, the upper half pore density $( \mathrm { N } _ { \mathrm { v } } , )$ and lower half pore density $( \mathrm { N } _ { \mathrm { v } } \mathrm {            } _ { - } )$ are defined as the number of pores formed in $z > 0$ and $\mathbf { z } \leq 0$ ,respectively,divided by one half of the total deposit volume.An increase in the $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ decreased $\mathrm { N } _ { \mathrm { v } + }$ for all substrate widths but decreased the lower half pore density for the ${ \bf w } = 0 . 5$ and $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 8 \ : \mathrm { m m }$ substrate deposits. Fig.7A shows a decreasing trend in $\mathrm { N } _ { \mathrm { v } + }$ when the substrate width and $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ increased,which showed a similar trend to that of the total pore density.Fig.7B shows that $\mathrm { N } _ { \mathrm { v } , - }$ had a decreasing trend in the $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 5$ and the $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 8 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ substrate deposits,however,an increasing trend in $\mathrm { N } _ { \mathrm { v } \mathrm { - } }$ was observed in $\mathrm { w } = 1 . 0$ and $\textbf { w } = \ 2 . 0 \ \mathrm { \ m m }$ substrate deposits as higher $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ was applied. Furthermore, the porosity in the as-deposited condition was predominantly located in the $0 < \mathbf { z } \leq 0 . 8 \mathbf { r }$ region for the different deposit substrate widths,as shown in Fig.7C.From this data,itis clear that these pores were mostly reduced through the LR process.

content: The effect of the LR process on total pore volume was also evaluated. Fig.8 shows the total porosity $\left( \mathrm { P _ { v } } \right)$ ,or void fraction,at different substrate widths and applied LR energies. $\mathbf { P _ { V } }$ is defined as the percentage of the total pore volume to the total deposit volume.For a substrate width of $w = \{ 0 . 5 ,$ 0.8, 1.0, $2 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m } \}$ ,the as-deposited pore volume fraction was $\mathrm { P _ { v } } = \{ 0 . 1 1 3$ ,0.130,0.107, $0 . 0 7 2 ~ \% \}$ . At $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 5 \ \mathrm { m m }$ ,increasing laser remelting energy density of $\mathrm { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } } ~ = ~ \{ 1 7 . 5$ ，26.3, $5 2 . 5 ~ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 2 } } \}$ decreased pore volume to $\mathrm { { P _ { v } } = \{ 0 . 1 0 3 , 0 . 0 4 5 , 0 . 0 1 8 \ \% \} }$ . This same behavior was seen for each substrate width.At the highest laser remelting energy of $\mathrm { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } } = 5 2 . 5 ~ \mathrm { J / m m } ^ { 2 }$ ，the pore volume was $\mathbf { P _ { V } } =$ $\{ 0 . 0 1 8 , 0 . 0 4 0 , 0 . 0 7 2 , 0 . 0 4 5 \ \% \}$ for $\mathbf { w } = \{ 0 . 5 , 0 . 8 , 1 . 0 , 2 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m } \}$ ，this corresponding to reductions of {85, 69, 33, $3 8 \% \}$ ,respectively.

content: The localized effect of the LR process in the upper regions of the deposit is evident in the evolution of the distribution of the pore volume for the upper and lower regions of the deposited bead,detailed in Fig. 9. An increase in $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ decreased both porosity in the upper half of the deposit $( \mathrm { P } _ { \mathrm { v } + } )$ and lower half of the deposit $( \mathrm { P } _ { \mathrm { v } } , \mathrm { - } )$ for the $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 5$ and 0.8 mm substrate deposits,but it decreased $\mathrm { \bf P _ { v , + } }$ and increased $\mathrm { P } _ { \mathrm { v } , - }$ was observed for the $\mathrm { \mathbf { w } } = 1 . 0$ and $2 . 0 \mathrm { m m }$ substrate deposits.Fig.9a shows a decrease in $\mathrm { P _ { v + } }$ for all widths $\mathbf { w } = \lbrace 0 . 5 ,$ 0.8,1.0, $2 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m } )$ from $\{ 0 . 1 7 _ { : }$ 0.19,0.15, $0 . 0 9 ~ \% \}$ in as-deposited samples to {0.020,0.017,0.026, $0 . 0 0 4 \ \% \}$ when the highest $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ was applied, respectively. The porosity in the lower half of the deposit, $\mathrm { P } _ { \mathrm { v } \mathrm { - } }$ decreased for substrate widths of w $= \{ 0 . 5 , 0 . 8 \ \mathrm { m m } \}$ ,but increased when $\mathbf { w } = \{ 1 . 0 , 2 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m } \}$ ,This shows that LR process was most effective at $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 5 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ with $\mathbf { P _ { V } }$ reduced throughout the entire deposit.For the samples produced,the majority of the pore volume existed in $0 < \mathbf { z } \leq 0 . 8 \mathbf { r }$ region, but little to no pores existed at $\mathbf { z } \le - 0 . 4 \mathbf { r }$ and $z > 0 . 8 \mathrm { r }$ for all substrate widths in the asdeposited samples,as shown in Fig. 9C.

content: A two-sample t-test was conducted to determine if a statistically significant difference was seen between the upper and lower half porosity levels.Table 2 shows that there was no statistically significant difference between the average pore diameter of the upper $\left( \mathrm { D } _ { + } \right)$ and lower half (D_） in the as-deposited $0 . 5 \ \mathrm { m m }$ sample,whereas the asdeposited samples with substrate widths of ${ \bf w } = \{ 0 . 8  $ ，1.0, $2 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m } \}$ showed statistically significant difference at $\alpha = 0 . 0 2$ .Typically, $\mathbf { D _ { - } }$ was larger than $\mathrm { D } _ { + }$ for all substrate widths with and without LR.However, when the highest $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ was applied,these distributions did not show a statistically significant difference in all substrate widths.This implies the energy applied by the LR process homogenizes the size of the pores. It was observed that the highest $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ process increased the average pore size for substrate widths of $\mathbf { w } = \{ 0 . 5 , 0 . 8 , 1 . 0 \mathrm { m m } \}$ ,whereas itdecreased the average pore size in the $\mathbf { w } = 2 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m }$ substrate deposit.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r-part-23
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r.md
content:
# 3.3.Surface roughness characterization
The roughness parameters $( S _ { \mathrm { a } } , S _ { \mathrm { q } } , S _ { \mathrm { s k } } , \Omega$ $s _ { \mathrm { k u } } ,$ and $\mathbf { S } _ { \mathrm { d r } } \mathbf { \dot { \Omega } }$ ）were calculated from scanned surfaces of each deposit and were analyzed to determine the effect of the substrate width and LR process parameters.The optical images show apparent unmelted powders on the surface of the deposits as shown in Fig.1OA-D.When LR was applied, these surfaces clearly were smoothed with reduced protrusions and flatness as evident in the profilometer measurements shown in Fig.1OE,F,G,Hand Table 3.

Table 3 presents the summary roughness parameters for the different samples and Fig.11 shows the evolution of the $S _ { \mathbf { a } }$ and $s _ { \mathrm { q } }$ parameters. Asdeposited samples showed a decrease in surface roughness due to LR with $\mathsf { S _ { a } } = 4 . 1 5 9 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $ { \mathbf { S } } _ { \mathrm { q } } = 6 . 3 6 6 ~  { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ being the smoothest surface roughness LR could achieve in the current study. Increased LR energy density generally reduced $S _ { \mathrm { a } }$ with diminishing reduction at higher energy densities.Initially, $S _ { \mathrm { a } }$ ranged from 11 to $1 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and this fell to 6-10 $\mu \mathrm { m }$ with a low LR energy density of $1 7 . 5 \ : \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 2 } }$ $S _ { \mathrm { a } }$ stabilized at $4 { \mathrm { - } } 6 \mu \mathrm { m }$ with increasing energy density. Comparatively,reduction in $s _ { \mathrm { q } }$ saturated rapidly for all substrate widths at $6 { - } 7 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ and appeared to be relatively insensitive to increasing energy density.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r-part-24
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r.md
content:
To characterize the effect of substrate width and LR process on microstructure, deposits with $\mathrm { E _ { L R } } = \{ 0 , 1 7 . 5 , 5 2 . 5 J / \mathrm { m m } ^ { 2 } \}$ on $\mathbf { w } = \lbrace 0 . 5 ,$ $2 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m } \}$ were analyzed. Primary dendritic arm spacing (PDAS), secondary dendritic arm spacing (SDAS),and grain size were measured using optical microscopy.All samples exhibited some degree of columnar grain structure at the interface between substrate and the deposit with equiaxed grains interspersed.Grain morphology was elongated roughly perpendicular to the interface boundary.The boundary was formed convex upward in the $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 5 \mathrm { m m }$ substrate with columnar grains at the interface (Fig.l2B,green arrow),whereas the boundary was formed convex down in the $\mathbf { w } = 2 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m }$ substrate with columnar grains at the interface (Fig.12D,green solid arrow).Columnar grains were followed by coarser equiaxed grains in the middle section of the beads,and finer equiaxed grains were formed in the side peripheral regions.The direction of columnar grains was pointing towards the substrate indicating that this would be the thermal gradient between the deposit and substrate.

Table 3 Calculated surface roughness parameters.

fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r.md
content: With the application of LR,a new melt pool boundary was created where the microstructure was distinctly different.The area of remelted region grew as $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ increased.More columnar grains (Fig.12B,blue dotted arrow) were created by the LR process at the top region of the deposit where the laser partially remelted the deposited bead, growing perpendicularly from the newly created molten pool boundary (Fig.l2B,E,F red dotted line).The solidified material resulted in a columnar grain structure and in the heat afected zone and larger equiaxed grains, this has been observed elsewhere [26].When $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { { L R } } } =$ $5 2 . 5 ~ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 2 } }$ was applied, the grain size in the entire bead changed for the deposit on the $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 5 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ substrate.The columnar grains with $\mathrm { P D A S } = 7 . 7 3 1 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ in the as-deposited samples disappeared,and the substrate-deposit interface boundary was flattened.Also,the size of cellular grains at the top of the deposit decreased from $1 7 . 4 9 4 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ to $1 3 . 1 1 1 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ .For the $\mathbf { w } = 2 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m }$ substrate,only grains in the top of the deposit were mostly affected despite having $5 5 ~ \%$ smaller deposit radius than that of the $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 5 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ substrate.The deposit kept its columnar $\mathtt { P D A S } = 4 . 2 0 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ at the bottom of the bead with and without the highest $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ (Fig.l2F).Without the LR process,internal and peripheral cellular grain size of the $\mathbf { w } = 2 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m }$ substrate were $5 . 5 6 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ and $4 . 0 7 8 ~  { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ respectively,compared to $3 4 . 5 8 9 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $1 7 . 4 9 4 \mu \mathrm { m }$ for the $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 5 \mathrm { m m }$ substrate.

content: The experiments above have made use of 3D XCT reconstructions, 3D optical surface scans and optical microscopy to quantify the radius, distribution and removal of pores,surface roughness and grain structures in more detail than has been previously studied.The data was used to elucidate the mechanism of deposit and pore formation and reduction in LR.In the ensuing,the effects on geometry,porosity,roughness,and microstructure are described.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r-part-30
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r.md
content:
# 4.1． Geometry analysis
Generally,a higher energy density corresponds with a larger melt pool area and hence larger deposits on thick and wide substrates [27,28].It was initially hypothesized that a wider substrate would result in larger deposits because of the increased area for powder catchment around the laser source.Further,with the $1 . 0 \mathrm { m m }$ laser spot size,it was initially presumed that any deposit on a less than $\mathbf { w } = 1 . 0 \mathrm { m m }$ substrate would have had smaller deposits because of the size of the melt pool. However,it was observed in the present study that the same deposition energy density on narrower substrates resulted in larger deposits.In this case, the radius of deposit on the narrower substrate was $4 6 ~ \%$ greater than that on the wide substrate even without LR.This could be due to a number of reasons.First,the impact of the energy absorbed by the substrate may be more significant in the narrower substrate which may lead to a larger melt pool or increase the remelt area.In this case, the energy absorbed by the narrower substrates likely could not be dissipated quickly enough [24].The effect of LR on deposit radius diminished for wider substrates due to a faster cooling rate from larger substrate mass acting as a heat sink.In other works,the use of similar energy density on substrates with smaller cross-sectional areas led to inconsistent bead geometry causing bulging and wavy tracks [29,30]. These inconsistent geometries were linked to uneven temperature distribution causing different density and surface tension between the molten pool and rapidly solidifying track [30].

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r-part-31
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r.md
content: The XCT scans revealed evolution of the spatial distribution of porosity with the LR process.In the powder-blown directed energy deposition process,the substrate is melted along with the feed powder in the melt pool,followed by solidification.In this process,the lower region of the melt pool would contain larger portions of melted substrate, whereas the upper regions would mostly consist of melted powders that contain internal pores by gas trapping in production [31,32]. From the present results,this statement is supported by showing the majority of pore counts $( 6 5 - 7 5 \% )$ and pore volume $( 6 1 - 7 4 \%$ existing in the upper half of the as-deposited samples regardless of the substrate widths. However,pore density $\mathrm { N } _ { \mathrm { v } , \mathrm { t } }$ decreased as the substrate width increased. When substrate width was increased from $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 5 \ : \mathrm { m m }$ to {0.8,1.0,2.0 $\mathrm { m m } \}$ $\mathrm { N } _ { \mathrm { v } , + }$ and $\mathrm { N } _ { \mathrm { v } , - }$ decreased by {22,37, $5 7 \ \% \}$ and {41,47, $5 0 ~ \% \}$ respectively.Ahigher laser energy density typically results ina larger melt pool area as well asa lower porosity [27,28],but this does not account for changes in the substrate width,so this alone cannot explain why $\mathrm { N _ { v } }$ is higher with narrower substrates.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r-part-32
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r.md
content: We hypothesize that porosity formation is closely related to the size of the melt pool for the given condition.With a larger melt pool at $\mathbf { w } =$ $0 . 5 \mathrm { m m }$ ,more metal powder is captured,but the input energy per melt pool volume may not be enough to melt the powder completely.Preexisted pores in the powder,unmelted particles,or voids between particles could all be submerged into the melt pool and entrapped due to less absorbed energy density per melt pool volume [33].Having larger melt pool could also increase the chance of entrapping argon gas from shielding/carrier gas flow [34].Itis proposed that pore density formed ina single-track deposit is positively correlated to the diameter of the melt pool. With the LR process,the competition among pore velocity, the Marangoni-driven flow,and solidification rate determines formation and reduction of pore count and volume.In the upper regions of the deposits,higher ELR resulted in lesser number and volume of pores $( \mathrm { { N } } _ { \mathrm { { v } } , + }$ and $\mathrm { \bf p } _ { \mathrm { v } + } )$ . This was because the upper region experienced higher energy by being closer to the applied energy,this giving enough time for the pores to escape or close before the melt pool solidified.In the lower regions of the deposits,however, the substrate width had effects on resulting porosity.At substrate width of $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 5 \ : \mathrm { m m }$ ,deposits showed decrease in $\mathrm { N } _ { \mathrm { v } \mathrm { - } }$ and $\mathrm { P } _ { \mathrm { v } \mathrm { - } }$ with LR,however,deposits showed the increased $\mathrm { N } _ { \mathrm { v } \mathrm { - } }$ and $\mathrm { P } _ { \mathrm { v } \mathrm { - } }$ at $\mathbf { w } = \{ 1 . 0 , 2 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m } \}$ .As for the wider substrates,the lower half of the bead had a cooling rate of an order of magnitude higher than that of narrower substrates.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r-part-33
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r.md
content: This would have resulted in a short solidification time of the melt pool which would have hindered the ability of pores in the region to escape.It could also be possible that pores from the melt pool in the upper half were forced to the lower half by Marangoni flow or shielding gas flow to reason for increased $\mathrm { N } _ { \mathrm { v } , - }$ and $\mathrm { P } _ { \mathrm { v } , - }$ [35].On the other hand, for substrate width of $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 5 \ \mathrm { m m }$ ,the deposit would have experienced longer solidification time for the pores to escape.These results show significant effects of substrate width on pore reduction.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r-part-34
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r.md
content: Most additively manufactured deposits using powder DED inherently have high surface roughness due to insufficient melting of the powder or balling effect [29,36].The size of the protruded defects is in the size range of the powder; therefore the surface defect could be due to the blown-powder sticking to the surface of near-solidifying molten pool after laser passes and balling effect from a splashed droplets [37].The application of LR in this study reduced surface roughness as measured by $\mathbf { S _ { a } }$ by $4 0 { \mathrm { - } } 6 0 \ \%$ with greater reductions being attributed with greater LR energy density.This is consistent with other works that have shown that an $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ of $3 0 \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 2 } }$ is effective in reducing surface roughness by $8 0 \%$ in selective laser melting (SLM) and selective laser sintering (SLS)[12,38]. Although the highest $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ resulted in the most reduced $s _ { \mathrm { a } } ,$ a lower $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ of $2 6 . 3 \mathrm { \ J / m m ^ { 2 } }$ was more suitable on thin wall deposition to prevent overheating and melting of the substrate.When $\mathrm { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } } = 1 7 . 5 ~ \mathrm { J / m m } ^ { 2 }$ was applied, the remelted surface on the deposit was narrow which explains the limited reduction in $\mathbf { S _ { a } }$ .Even at $2 6 . 3 ~ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 2 } }$ ,the surface defects on the side of the deposit were not effectively removed.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r-part-35
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r.md
content: High $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ was observed to also introduce more inconsistency in deposition geometry on a thin-walled substrate. An increase in energy density creates a larger amount of liquid phase and greater diameter of the molten track.On the wider substrate,the shape of the molten pool was supported by the substrate alongside it.This decreases the capillary instability of the molten pool which helps to reduce balling phenomena according to the perturbation theory [29,39].However,on a narrow substrate, the molten pool is wider than the substrate and is free to flow on either side of the substrate forced by the carrier and shielding gas blowing into the melt. $\mathbf { S } _ { \mathbf { s } \mathbf { k } }$ and $\mathtt { s } _ { \mathrm { k u } }$ of the height distribution revealed that samples exhibited peaks instead of valleys,and the peaks were sharp instead of round or flat. This means the surface had protrusions instead of pits，and those protrusions were relatively sharp representing unmelted powder or spatter. Decrease in $\mathbf { S } _ { \mathrm { d r } }$ further indicated flattening of the surface by LR.

name: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r-part-36
fileName: 2023 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Kim, Saldana - Post-processing of additively manufactured IN625 thin-walled structures using laser r.md
content:
Microstructure analysis provided apparent evidence of faster solidification cooling rate ina wider substrate by measuring smaller cellular grain size and PDAS.When substrate width was increased from $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 5$ to $\mathbf { w } = 2 . 0 \mathbf { m } \mathbf { m }$ ,the cellular grain size of $\mathbf { w } = 2 . 0 \mathrm { m m }$ deposit was at least four times smaller than that of $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 5 \ \mathrm { m m }$ both in peripheral and internal regions.The substrate width of $\mathbf { w } = 2 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m }$ has four times more mass than that of $\mathbf { w } = 0 . 5 \mathrm { m m }$ resulting the cooling rate and the capacity of the total heat being transferred from the deposit to the substrate. Studies have shown that the natural log of PDAS linearly decreases with increase in cooling rate,because it depends mainly on the temperature gradient, G $\left( \mathrm { K } / \mathrm { m m } \right)$ ,and dendrite tip growth rate,V $\mathrm { ( m m / s ) }$ [40,41]. Huang summarized an extensive statistical data of PDAS and its cooling rate from 11 nickel-based super alloys studies and created a regression analysis that resulted $\mathrm { C } _ { 2 } = 1 3 4 . 4 3 \ : \mathrm { m m }$ and $\mathbf { m } = 0 . 2 6$ [41].When these values were used in Eq. (5) with our sample data in Table 4,the experimental cooling rate was on the order of $1 0 ^ { 4 }$ to $1 0 ^ { 5 } ~ \mathrm { K } / s$ 、The results showed that increased substrate width across the conditions investigated resulted in a tenfold cooling rate.

The cellular dendrite spacing at the LR boundary region of $\mathbf { w } = \lbrace 0 . 5 ,$ $2 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m } \}$ at $\mathrm { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } } = 1 7 . 5 ~ \mathrm { J / m m } ^ { 2 }$ was smaller than that of the deposit processed at $\mathrm { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } } = 5 2 . 5 \mathrm { J / m m } ^ { 2 }$ ,as shown in Fig.13E,F,and Fig.14E,F, which infers that cooling rate is higher atlower $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ .This is also observed at the peripheral region of the deposit at the top (Fig.13B,C,Fig.14B, C).Similar observations have been made in Ref.[44],where monotonic decrease in cooling rate was observed with increase in laser power [44]. Moreover, the secondary dendritic arm formation was suppressed in the $\mathbf { w } = 2 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m }$ substrate deposit because of high cooling rate [30].

content:
This study evaluated the efect of the LR process on thin-substrate deposit characteristics and defects by varying $\operatorname { E } _ { \mathrm { L R } }$ and substrate width. The following conclusions were made:

1.Given the same deposition parameters,the radius of single-track deposit was inversely proportional to the substrate width, because more substrate mass melts in narrower substrate deposition leading to more melt pool volume.LR did not significantly affect the geometry of the deposit.
